number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
y 2
												[NO SPOILERS]If ever there was a game that was judged by association, this it it.More than anything, Invisible War is judged by the Deus Ex in it's name. Before it is even installed, it is expected to be at least as good and preferably better than one of the greatest games of all time. Hardly fair odds.As a result many people don't see anything other than the fact that Invisible War is not the same as the original Deus Ex. It doen't get a chance to stand on it's own and be judged on merit.It's like starting a music career by being told that if you don't do better than The Beatles, you are a complete failure.IMO Invisible War should be seen not as the sequel to Deus Ex, but as a different game in the same universe. The was Thor is not a sequel to Iron Man, but simply a different film set in the same universe.While there are many of the same themes and elements, the end products are not the same.If judged on it's own merit, Invisible War is a pretty great game. Sure, the levels are small, but they are well designed and offer many gameplay options.The shooting is competent. Much better than it ever was in Deus Ex. Controls are well above most games of it's time.It's no secret that many things were dumbed down from Deus Ex. While I do prefer the old, more advanced system which gave more player options, the new, simpler system is perfectly functional. And given the in-game time gap between the two games, such changes can easily be explained by technological development. Just look at the difference in weapons from WW1 to WW2.One major point that divides people is the universal ammo. Personally, I think it's interesting. While it doesn't make much logical sense that all types of weapons would use the same ammo, it does bring something new to the game.Since different weapons use different amounts of ammo with each shot, inventory management becomes more important. Especially for people like me who in most games are used to just using the pistol 95% of the time and therefore always having plenty of ammo for the big guns. In Invisible War you can't just squirrel away lots of ammo for the big guns and save it for the big enemies. Now you actually have to plan ahead from time to time.While it's not a system I would like to see widely used in games, I do find it interesting.Bottom line:I personally think Invisible War is a very solid game. It is unfairly judged by it's association with a game it could never live up to.Take it as a single game and judge it on it's own merit. Do that and you will likely find that it is much better than people give it credit for. In fact, it is very good game.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2015
												If this game has taught me anything, it is to take what others say with a grain of salt. I went into this expecting an experience akin to that of arm wrestling with a chainsaw, but I guess that everyone's talk of this game lowered my expectations to unreasonable depths. Invisible War is, while not as good as its predecessor, a good game.A big complaint I notice is the "consolization", the clear downgrade in many aspects of the overall design of the first game, including large levels, complex controls, dynamic damage, skills, and swimming. (The multiplayer is gone as well.) There is a lack of control options, which correlated directly to removal of leaning, reduced toolbelt size and biomod (augmentation) slots, and an ugly HUD. As for the size of areas, I would chalk that up to incredibly sloppy coding and graphics that were ahead of their time. One might look at the game's system requirements and then remember that this released in North America in 2003. However, as far as I'm concerned, it is still little excuse; The smaller areas force a different style of gameplay, and the frequency and time of the loading screens is just annoying.Atmosphere-wise, there is nothing wrong. The graphics are great, and the story, a direct sequel, I would say surpasses that of the original, at least in terms of depth. In terms of how memorable the characters are... eh, I don't really have much to say. Open-ended missions change the flow of the game. Rather than being given one main objective at a time a la the first game, the player is given multiple objectives from warring factions that ultimately branch to the end, and make the ending seem like more of a result of the path taken throughout the game, rather than a rushed decision made at the last minute, though the latter is certainly still possible should you enjoy being chaotic in choosing your allies.Sadly, if the story is more open than the original, the same cannot be said for weapons and inventory management. Multitools and lockpicks are now one and the same. Items now only take up one slot each, so there is no need for inventory Tetris, but the small size can only be increased by installing and upgrading a specific biomod. Food can be stacked regardless of the type. Firearms have universal ammo, which I saw to be a self-defeating mechanism. In the original Deus Ex, running out of ammo for a weapon forced me to rethink my entire combat strategy and apply it until I could renew my supplies. Here, run out for one gun, you run out for just about everything else. On top of that, weapons can only take two mods at a time, and mods cannot be removed once applied.Even with a decent variety of weapons, I found little point to using nonlethal tactics. At least during the first few hours of the first game, you would get reprimanded for it. Here, there is almost never a reason to not just kill enemies on the spot. Even when I do use a nonlethal weapon, the game treats the character as having died, and he or she will not appear again. The small area sizes, while not too restrictive, encourage more aggressive gameplay by giving very limited options as to approach.The player has fewer biomods/augmentations at one time. Luckily, many of the classics are here, as well as some new ones to compensate for the ones which were pulled. The best change here is having three to choose from for any specific slot, and the ability to change between them should you have the materials. It's a fine way to keep the player from restarting when he's realized that the combination he's chosen to go with is ineffective.I'm certain I've left something out, but this review has to end sometime. Even with all of its simplification problems, it manages to cling enough to the core Deus Ex gameplay. I plan on coming back to this sometime in the future, as I'm certain there's a lot more for me to discover, and the mission structure provides a great deal of replay value. Methinks people would treat this game better were it not called Deus Ex, but as it stands, Invisible War is a fine addition to the series.

8, 2016
												For fans of the original game, this might not seem as your piece of cake. At first... The huge areas in the original game are switched out with small, claustrophobic areas and you will encounter a bunch of loadingscreens. The game also has some nasty bugs, which will require some tweaking in txt. files to fix (res, fov amongst others), but for Windows 10 users, not all problems can be fixed (the game minimizes to desktop for each loadingacreen, and then opens itself a few seconds later and continues the loading. This can only be fixed in Win 8 and older).The cool "tetris" inventory system from the original game has been replaced with an impractical new inventory, and there is no longer different ammo types for different weapons. The gunplay is pretty bad, and it is pretty much impossible to sneak past enemies without being noticed (except if you use a biomod).On the positive side, the graphics have been improved and you don't want to miss the story, as it explains what happened after the events in Deus Ex. The core gameplay is the same, and there are still several possibilities on how to complete a level.All in all I recommend the game, simply because it is still Deus Ex, even though many things have been executed far worse in this game. True fans of the first game definitely shouldn't miss the story of this game :)

												finally after 13 years struggling to make it work properly , i played it and finished it .-. and you can say that this is the last true deus ex game from the true devs ( i highly recommend you to play the first DE to understand what is happening in this one) .-starting with the plot ( a short and slow but non lineaire plot) , it takes off 20 years after the events of the first game you can play as a male or female clone of JC Danton you got multiple quests ( mains and side quests) from different factors that affect the progression of the main plot ( 4 different ending ) i find it a bit short compared to the first deus ex game 15h compared to 35h ( it feels kinda rushed) .-graphicly it's not that bad of course it did not age well but you can find an HD texture pack that makes the game looks a bit better and some tweaks to make it run at widescreen resolution .-perfect voice acting ( + the different accents i love that in a game ), sound effects are also great , music is excellent just like in deus ex 1.-gameplay didnt change a lot from the first game, changing plot + multiple quests , but what they changed is the inventory and the augmentation, the inventory is limited to 10 slots ( doesnt matter the size of the thing ) and you can only get 5 augmentations so you have to choose wisely ( depends on your style ) people will hate it like i did in the beginning but i think it was a good chose what they did (you play as a low quality-like clone of JC so its normal to get limitation in power)-there is flaws and crashes (took almost 10 years to correct them by the community) so you just have to go to google or the steam community and you will find the fixed.-no achievements or cards and no steam chat during gameplay .-worth the price but you can get it for like 1.5$ on sales.i recommend this one for those who like slow and non lineaire intriguing plot8/10

content:
ber 13, 2016
												Give it a little patience, download the improved Unified Texture pack made by a fan, patch to 1080 resolution, and this game is quite a good game.It came from the Eidos era or 2003, which is the same era as Tomb Raider Angel of Darkness,  which could have a great game, but Eidos of this era pushed development teams very hard and had impossibly short deadlines, etc. While AOD wore the brunt of these behind the scenes problems, Deus Ex: Invisible War managed to be at least a coherant complete game. With some problems, sure.Its biggest problem may be that it has to live up to the incredible success of the first game. A hard task by itself. And does it? Yes and no. While it does not start with the same atmosphere as the first game, after a few levels, and after a few biomod upgrades, it becomes more obvious that it really does exist in the same game world as the opiginal. It is not as long of a game, and its a pity that it ends not very long after reaching its full momentum, but there is enough Role Playing and Action to be fresh and entertaining.The zones are divided into sections makes it feel less open world in the "safe areas" (i.e. non combat zones where as opposed to zones with 90% combat) that, say, Hong Kong did in the first game. And even on a modern (2016) pc, loading is a bit slow. On Windows 10, you get to see your desktop for at least 10 seconds of loading, and I doubt there will be any patch to fix this in the future. This just means that loading between sub areas can break the momentum and mood slightly. However, there is enough complexity and there are enough missions in the "safe areas". Also each map, while following the city architecture, is different enough to justify it being stored in seperate zones. It would be nice if it was remade in one unified map, but that is unlikely to ever happen. However, it shouldnt ruin the experience.I've seen many people complain about the UI, which is different to most first person games. I personally liked it. Its circular rather than linear, and that is really the only difference compared to other first person games. Unlike most games, you get to choosethe UI colour. I liked that I could choose a nice subtle red colouor. However, I had some minor issues with the controls. Pressing action on locked objects like doors or chests automatically changed your currently held item to the multi-tool lockpick. Which is fine when you arent in combat, but, if you accidently hit action during combat while beside a locked door or chest, you find yourself trying to defeat the opponent with a lockpick instead of your weapon of choice. The other minor thing, you dont have a "put the item away" button, so its possible to forget you have your weapon out in a non combat zone and accidently shoot an npc. Two minor issues that generally shouldnt be a problem if you are paying attention to what you are doing.And that is about it. But to summarise:- It can take some time to setup on a 2016 PC, but there are community guides in the game's section on steam to help with this. Get the improved textures and resolution fixes.- Its slow to get into the pace of a Deus Ex game, but well worth giving the time to reach its full pace. Sadly I would have liked that pace to have lasted 2-3 additional levels but it is stilla  full complete game that is worth the time.- There will be many loading screens, but do not let that give you the feeling that the game itself is small.- There are some minor UI issues but nothing truely problematic.

content:
, 2015
												Being a huge fan of the Deus Ex series, I had high hopes going into Deus Ex: Invisible War. The story starts off with Alex, an Orphan, raised by a couple in Chicago and put into a special schoolfor gifted children, where she eventually found her way into the Taurus program, a human augmentation program. You start off being attacked by religious fanatics and are given both sides point of view, with each side trying to persuade you the other is the real threat. Interesting story, I like the concept and it had be playing for over an hour, when I only intended a short demo for the review. It appears to further the Deus Ex Canon, and while it has all the wonderful potential of a Deus Ex game, I will warn you now there are bugs.First of all, every time the game wants to load a new area, It jumps back to your desktop for a a few seconds and the resolution change makes your desktop appear to be supersized. It does this a lot. The graphics are not quite up to par for a sequel to Deus Ex, but it is passable. The game almost has a feel as though it were rushed or poorly ported from a handheld or console. I think it would be a prime candidate for a reboot, as it was interesting. All in all I will recommend it, but only to those who are familiar with the Deus Ex series, so as to acquire this piece of Deus Ex Canon for your collection. Otherwise, if you are looking for a quality game, and don't care about the series, the Original is great, and Deus Ex: Human Revolution is fantastic. Either way, the series is solid.

												The gameplay might be simpler, the setting more clichéd and the duration shorter, but the ideals of the old ‘Looking Glass Aesthetic’ remain intact. If you care about this, you’ll love Invisible War like your own child.Judged on its own merits, Invisible War is a great example of a game that offers meaningful freedom of choice, that rewards different approaches and that creates a coherent, intelligent world wrapped up in a very well paced and expertly written plot.Sure, some people will say that the game's made too many concessions to convenience -- no more skills and one kind of ammo spring to mind -- but all this means is that you have fewer concerns distracting you from the main point of the game, your experience making decisions within the game's story.Overall, this is was one of the most captivating and thoroughly polished titles of its time.

content:
2, 2016
If you're not lucky enough to have the game work right off the bat, or you're not willing to spend a bit (around 5 minutes at least, 30 minutes at most) setting it up to make it work properly, I wouldn't recommend it. Read the near the end for problems I had playing it.There are many differences between Deus Ex: Invisible War and the first game, for example:The maps are fairly smaller.The skills and augmentations have been combined into biomods.As the skills have been removed, you are pretty much as proficient with your weapons in the beginning as you are in the end, unless you are using weapon mods or melee biomods.Despite the skills and augmentations being removed in favor of biomods, there are still many different ways to play the game.Problems I had playing the gameThe game didn't allow me to change to windowed mode without manually editing the config, as it was not in the options menu.As far as I know, by default the game doesn't support aspect ratios outside of 4:3, or changing the resolution to anything besides what the default options menu supports. When I tried either of these, the text in menus often disappeared, and sometimes the game just didn't render at all.Loading screens often took minutes to load, I believe I fixed this by closing the Logitech Gaming Framework (lcore.exe). Combined with the small areas, which means more minute-long loading screens, it is very annoying to play with this issue.Like I said, if you don't want to spend time trying to fix it (I almost gave up myself, it took me about an hour before I realized that setting a custom resolution was causing the second problem I stated above), I wouldn't recommend this game. I'd say that it is definitely worth spending some time to get it working though.If you like the Deus Ex story and world, or you're looking for a fairly simpler version of the first Deus Ex (gameplay-wise) I'd definitely recommend this game, however.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Now hold on here. Hold your horses. This game is not as bad as people say. Not by a long shot.Sure it is nothing like Human Revolution, and sure it was a bit of a departure from the original title. Sure it was made for the xBox and suffered from some small environments, but this was a great game, one of the few games I have ever honest-to-god completed (something which, honest to god, doesn't apply to the original, which was just a little too outdated when I came back to it to try and win through where I had lost interest back in the early 00s)Put in some hours and you might experience some nice surprises! The graphics might improve dramatically as you venture deeper into the experience, the level design too! The alternate routes that are so famous in the series are right there, waiting for you to exploit them, and the combat is satisfying.A bit of intrigue does exist, and the controls work well. The story is a lot longer than you expect it to be, and the levels really well made.Honestly, this is a really fun game, even if it is a little previous-previous-gen. Frankly at certain times the graphics are so well handled that you could be forgiven for mistakenly thinking you were playing a much more recent game.It is a real shame that this game got such a bad wrap. It was never the same as the original in so many ways, but in a lot of unexpected ways it was a little bit better, and it was a really wonderful taster of the potential of the series in a next-gen world, a taster for a the utter banquet that would be Deus Ex: Human Revolution, my favourite game of all time.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												If You think about playing DX:IW there is a good chance that You came across its older brother, DX.Either You hated it because at first glance the options were overwhelming, playing it like a shooter was hard and frustrating or loved it for its complexity, the richness of the world, the great storytelling.Either way, there are good news and bad news for You.I was one of those who disliked DX:IW when it came out. This was the time of a new console generationt and these swallowed a large proportion of the gaming community - and this was one of the first games the developers clearly created with console gamers in mind.This meant that the user interface was oversimplified and blocked half of the view, that the game was not properly optimized for PC, that the creators had to settle for smaller level size or decreased game complexity.All the above meant that in the eyes of most PC gamers DX:IW was an unbecoming second installation to its truly amazing predecessor.I played it through then halfheartedly, and then again and again with more and more enthusiasm. Now, 10 years later I will summarize my opinion as I see this game today, sometimes in comparison with DX.First our old grievances:- 10 years passed, so the lack of optimization is not an issue anymore,- there are community packs to make it look bettter, looks good for its age,- smaller levels meant more loading (game settings were broken up into smaller levels) but with today's PCs this only takes a moment - also not a problem anymore,- hud can be customized via mods.Bad that did not change (a matter of taste, for You all these can be aadvantagious):- still oversimplified: awkward inventory management, less augmentations, no skill system, universal ammo is stupid, less background info through holomail or newspapers, etc,- male protagonist looks and sounds like a member of a boy band,- stealth gaming style does not always work- no-kill approach does not work (in DX it was only one person You really had to kill to advance in the story)Good that will remain good til the end of times (some of these I have learnt to appreciate only on my subsequent walkthroughs):- somehow the writer(s) managed to incorporate all three DX game endings into the sequel, so whichever ending You are familiar with, You will easily find Your bearings and understand the premise,- sidequests are fun and inspired,- new augs (though fewer) are fun to use,- similarly the new weapon mods are useful and fun,- great level design means that most of the time You still can choose between covert or guns-blazing approach,- one of the best intros of its time,- great NPC additions like the OMAR or NG Resonance,- amazing places to visit like Antarctica, Trier or Cairo (including an arcology building which looks good and feels right)All in all in my eyes funnily enough with age the game got better. It might feel disappointing after playing DX (or liberating, if You like less complexity), but a great game on its own right. Where DX gets A+++, DX:IW is worth an A- easily.Recommended.

content:
1, 2015
 My Adventure with DX:IW  TL:DR Version:  Couldn't even get it to run, compatibility issues abound, don't waste your money. I really wanted to play this game having just finished the original Deus Ex and Human Revolution and loving them both. I know this game has gotten a lot of hate so I wanted to see if it really stood for it or if that was just the angry nostalgia talking... Too bad I was never able to find out. Right off the bat the game wouldn't run, it would sit on a black screen and do nothing as task manager repeatedly warned that it was not responding. Eventually I found a fix for that and was able to get it started, and thought I was on the road to beginning the game, but a short time and an intro cutscene later the game threw my hopes of that out the window. I was able to choose my character and clicked the done button and then I was greeted by another black screen. I ended the task and the game refused to let my resolution go back to normal. After I went and manually turned it back, the game randomly decided to start back up, and I was thrust into the first level. I went through it and got to the next level, and again, another black screen. This one wouldn't go away no matter what I did. I searched forums and tried all sorts of "fixes" but none of them worked: compatibility settings, resolution changes, "fixed" start exes, even changing the affinity of the exe to a single core. None of these things worked. The only thing I didn't try that people said worked was a compatibility problem with Realtek audio drivers...which I wasn't about to uninstall all of my audio to run this game. Not worth it. So, having never gotten to play the game except for the first "level," I have to not recommend this game simply for it's horrible compatibility problems.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												This game gets kind of a bad rap, and it's easy to see why. For one, it's a sequel to one of the most heavily lauded games ever made. That automatically put it in the position of trying to live up to a nigh-impossible standard. But the game isn't bad, it's just very average. That's it's biggest problem, really: It's an average game that's a sequel to an amazing one. (Well, that and the stupid cover with the guy holding a pistol sideways.)Invisible War takes place about twenty years after Deus Ex. Events at the end of that game triggered something called "The Collapse", which basically crippled civilization and caused a wide variety of problems that people are still recovering from. In a way, the game implies that all three endings from DX1 sort-of happened: J.C. Denton attempted to merge with Helios but fails, which causes the global network to cease to function, which results in the downfall of national governments and the rise of "city-states". Some people have a problem with this, and while I'll certainly agree it could have been handled better, I'm not sure what people expected. Did they think that the developers would make three radically different settings depending on which ending you picked in the first game? You play as Alex D, a nanoaugmented student in the Tarsus Academy. Of course, things aren't what they seem, and just as in the original Deus Ex, you have to uncover a conspiracy and puzzle out what's really going on.The game plays out much as the original; you go from city to city performing missions, although in this game you get to choose whether you want to work for the Order (a religious group that springs up after the Collapse) or the World Trade Organization (which has more or less become the new version of the U.N. in this game). Which you choose does affect how the missions play out. However, it ultimately has no bearing on the way the game ends, which is another problem people have with it. I don't want to spoil the plot by explaining this, but I will say that I agree that the ultimate reveal is kind of dumb and renders a lot of your choices meaningless.Another story element that some people complain about is how several characters from the first game return, but have radically different points of view than in the first game. However, this complaint seems rather naive to me. First of all, it's been twenty years. People change a lot over that period of time. But more importantly, the characters in question were all directly involved in the events that triggered the Collapse. If your ideals led to a catastrophic event causing untold amounts of death and devastation, don't you think that might change your outlook?Gameplay-wise, the game is very similar to the original, but there are a few changes that were made to simplify things that ultimately work to the detriment of the game. The biomod system is less interesting, the level areas are smaller in order to accomodate the X-Box's memory limitations, but the worst change (and the one you will hear EVERYONE who plays this game ♥♥♥♥♥ about) is the ammunition system. In the original game (as in real life and in most FPSes), each weapon had its own ammunition, and in many cases a weapon had multiple ammo types you could choose between (for instance, shotguns had both buckshot and armor-piercing rounds). In this game, someone decided it would be a good idea to have every weapon use the same ammunition counter. The conceit is that the weapons are using nanomachines to build ammunition, and that your "ammo" is actually the raw material used to make bullets and whatnot. The biggest problem with this is that the amount of this material that you can carry is severely restricted, and heavy weapons take a huge amount of material to fire. If you, say, use a rocket launcher a few times, you may suddenly find yourself having no ammo for your pistol.Like I said: Overall, it's not a terrible game; it's just not good, either.It's easy to see why, when they made a third game, they chose to make it a prequel. Even if this had been a great game, it's hard to see where the series could go from here. I think the only way we're ever going to get a Deus Ex game set after the first one is if they reboot the original first... which, depending on how it's done, could be pretty cool, actually. If you're a fan of the original Deus Ex, I would recommend playing through Invisible War at least once to see for yourself what's good and what's bad about it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 27, 2016
												Although currently my steam ID says I beat this game in 10 hours, according to the save time it was actually 8 hours and 2 minutes. To put that in perspective it took me roughly 25-26 hours to beat the first Deus Ex the first time and around 15-16 to beat Mankind Divided, which almost everyone agrees is too short. This game is very short for a Deus Ex game, so don't expect the same amount of build up and revelation that you might have gotten in other games. For instance, in the first hour you discover that the illuminati still exist and are up to no good in the neighborhood. All of that being said, for the price that you can get this game on sale (around $2.49 I think) it's a solid chunk o' fun. You end up going to like 4 cities, so if you were ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that all of Mankind Divided took place in Prague, then this game might suit you.The most obvious problem with the game is that it was made for consoles, and by consoles I mean OLD consoles (like the first xbox). Therefore you won't get any large areas or levels. Even when they redo liberty island from the first game it is split into 3 different sections (not including UNATCO headquarters). The game was certainly not optimized for PCs and the game engine will crash if there are too many objects with physics. There were a few times when I was stuck because the game would spawn in enemies right after I had made a save and them spawning would crash the game. The way that I found would fix this was to destroy boxes and such that were using the physics engine, but such a problem shouldn't exist in such a simple (both graphically and mechanically) game. Sometimes it feels like no work went into the areas of the game because you generally run into the same features in each city.-A bar where you hire a pilot and progress the main objective-A locked off area where the final objective in that area will end up taking you-Apartments where you have to kill someone or something-The same factions and coffee shops (I know that it's important to the narrative for both of these, but seriously)IF I were to commend the game on one thing, it is that each city has roughly the same amount of secondary objectives. I remember when I played the first Deus Ex that all the side quests were in New York and places like Hong Kong had literally nothing to do but follow the main quest (despite Hong Kong being larger and better designed than New York).Really the only other reason I would recommend this game besides the fact that I like Deus Ex is that this game has some interesting lore. This game doesn't cling on to companies and characters from the first game (although it does include them) and the developers seem to have taken the time to try to develop new ideas. The most interesting that comes to mind is the Omar, who are like a more extreme version of Helios's final phase.Whatever. I like the game, it was okay, and most importantly it was cheap. Get it when it goes on sale.

content:
4
												I do recommend this game but it is not as good as the original Deus Ex.  The game just doesn't have the "pop" that the original Deus Ex has which makes you intrigued to keep playing the game and complete all of the side missions and explore all of the areas of the game.In this game, you do have a main mission and side missions.  The side missions tend to be a little lame, dealing with two coffee companies rivalry or letting someone know someone in the same bar is romantically interested in them.I did not like the universal ammunition in the game.  In the original game, the ammo you have for one type of weapon made you decide if you should attempt to attack some guards with a gun, blow them up with a rocket, or find a way to sneak around them because you did not have enough ammo in either weapons to take them on.  In this game, it is possible to sneak past them but you can pick whatever gun you like because the ammo for your pistol is the same as your shotgun.The biomodification in the game does help but only for some.  I HIGHLY recommend choosing the dampen foot noise modification because it will be very difficult to sneak around without it.  Later in the game, I had about 10 of the illegal biomodification and about 8 of the regular ones.  I guess it is helpful if you want to change what points you point into your biomodification but it does ruin the feel of making a hard choice to make your character unique in your play through.The story is all right and thankfully there isn't a lot of long cut scenes to the point where you feel like your watching a movie instead of playing a game.The last problem I had with the game was the occassional crashes.  Didn't happen too often and it may have been an issue with my computer.Overall, not a bad game to play but I would recommend playing it when it is on sale.

content:

												Don't listen to the public, play it for yourselfThough unfortunatley a product of it's time (janky physics anyone?), Invisible War really does not deserve a lot of the hate it gets. Being given the impossible task to try and stack up against its older brother (which is a MANDATORY play should you want to jump into this), of course it's going to seem mediocre. But when you weigh this game on it's own terms, is when its brilliance shows. Brilliant sound design, an even more dramatic and twisty narrative (actually allowing you to JOIN with specific factions this time around), solid mechanics and overall fun gameplay make for an enjoyable sci-fi/cyberpunk experience.But again, don't tangle yourself up in comparing it to the original Deus Ex. The mechanics are simplified, to the point to where it really isn't much of an RPG anymore, but they're polished enough to keep things enjoyable. And, unlike the previous game, truly allows you to pursue whatever playstyle you want without any strange setbacks/hiccups.Overall, great game, not so great sequel. 7/10 would definitley reccomend.

												(Disclamer, I orginally played this on the orginal xbox, and played most of my time with this game with steam offline)ah invisible war, don't believe the negative hype, this game is pretty good, it's not a masterpiece but it's not the bane of the series (i'm looking at you the fall). It tries to pick up where the orginal game left off storywise and tried the theme of corporate  warfare and corruption before Deus ex Human revolution could. If this wasn't directly linked to the deus ex series, then people would have given it an 8/10; however, then it would be missing the lore of the series that makes it great. so the moral of the story children is that: If you are a fan of the Deus Ex series, you owe it to play this to the end at least once for each of the endings.

content:
, 2015
												Deus Ex: Invisible War is a game that, in my opinion, receives WAY too much flak. Ok, it's not on the EXACT same level as the original, but the game is a must-buy for any true fan of the Deus Ex franchise. The gameplay is fun, challenging on occasion as it should be, and the story is very in-depth, as you would come to expect, with many Datacubes and News Terminals to hear about the world from. Other than the gripes outlined below, I can see no reason that this game gets as much crap as it does.#1 - The interface. It's just flat-out not as good as the original.#2 - Stability. I've not technically beaten this game yet. I only just now reached the abandoned VersaLife base near the end of the game, and I've been completely stopped dead in my tracks as far as Progression is concerned. I've been trying for little over 40 minutes now, and I crash almost every 1-2 minutes, or whenever I try to headshot someone with my sniper rifle.#3 - The Universal Ammo system. I shouldn't need to explain this one, but it essentially makes it very hard to have more than one weapon. I for one carry many different weapons, including a Silenced Pistol/Sniper Rifle, Shotgun, and a SMG. Shared ammo just doesn't work in a game like this.

content:
ry 13, 2016
												Deus Ex: Invisible War is a solid game with a great story, more focused on the action that the first part and simplifying the elements that were in this.PROS :- Continues and closes the storyline of the first part - Possibility to choose between a male or female protagonist with different options on their physical appearance.- Like the first part, what begins as a simple story unfolds in a story full of twists and complexities.- Like its predecessor, depending on the choices you make, you can change the style of the narrative or the relationship of certain NPC's toward the protagonist.- Is set on a Semi-Open World structure ala Wolfenstein (2009) for its narrative.- The exploration remains key for obtaining items, ammunition, rewards, etc.- Implementation of Havok Physics to move obstacles, hide corpses, attack, etc.- Multiple primary and secondary objectives to meet - Like the first part, there are multiple ways to meet the goals, reach a destination, get an item, etc.- Augmentations obtained and improved can be replaced by others once installed.- Integration of an ability to climb certain surfaces becomes quite useful.- Being a game more focused on the action than the first part, the combat is much more polished than its predecessor (Though the element of stealth is still present).- Most of the ranged weapons have a secondary fire mode.- Very good textures and lighting effects for its time CONS :- The protagonist, whatever male or female, does not have enough charisma.- Most NPC's share the same face.- Many elements are simplified when compared to its predecessor (No experience points for improve character skills, all guns share the same ammunition, many fewer weapons, the tool for hacking and lockpicking is the same one, etc.).- Improvements of the characters are limited exclusively to augmentations (As long as you have the item that allows you to install or upgrade these).- Each weapon only accept two modifications (From a total of eight options).- Control over jumps is sometimes a bit disastrous.- Many times, the use of physics in certain situations, is erratic and not let the situation settle directly or at the first attempt (Which can be a bit frustrating ).- The Quick-Load is not so "Quick".- The campaign lasts half the first Deus Ex (We are talking about a campaign of approximately 30 hours, although this is much more than the average for today's games).- An annoying Black-Screen bug present in the final length of the game when you load a Savegame

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21
												Hoo boy, Invisible War. Where do I begin? Well, first off, no, I don't think it's the worst Deus Ex game (that unfortunate honor goes to The Fall, and don't even get me started on GO), but that doesn't mean I think it's the best, either. There are some things I even believe go above and beyond what Deus Ex 1 did, like the fact that you can choose which faction you can side with, and it actually has consequences for who you decide to help. Granted, you can change sides at a whim, but it was much better than having the game say "nope, you're on this side now because your brother told you so" like the first game, and definitely miles above the later games in the franchise, which have no excuse for how linear they are. Hell, I'd even go as far to say that I prefer IW to the Squeenix DX titles in a good amount of ways.But, of course, as you've probably all heard, there are some issues with the game. Glaring issues, at that, the largest and most pervasive of which is the dumbing down of the systems relative to Deus Ex 1 in order to get the game running (and selling) on the original Xbox. Skill points are gone, with the skills they represented either gone completely or implemented into augmentations. Individual weapon ammunition gets the boot as well, with a universal ammo system that sounds good on paper but fails in implementation in their place. Independent limb damage also gets the boot, meaning that you can't blow your arms and legs off and crawl around using your nipples anymore. The levels have been shrunk in order to fit into the Xbox's 64 MB of RAM (a limitation that the PC port is also upheld to), which means more loading times as well. And, to top it all off, the script complexity got chopped down heavily in order to get it to look good at 480i on a CRT television.Unfortunately, on top of that, the game has not aged well in the slightest. Without a patch, it wigs out whenever it's played on a multi-core processor, it crashes frequently, and sometimes even refuses to boot for no discernable reason until you reboot your system. It also doesn't support widescreen displays without hex editing or special tools, and even then, it looks absolutely awful. The visuals (which I'm led to believe were a major cause for the levels being so small) are absolutely horrid by today's standards, even when compared to Deus Ex 1. This mainly comes down to the fact that all the humans rest firmly in the uncanny valley. The DX1 characters were awkward, blocky, and all looked the same, but it worked in their favor because the animation matched that. DX2 characters look realistic in comparison, but... Jesus, they're all grotesque. This falls on the animation, mainly. They animate almost exactly like the DX1 characters, and if you've ever seen DX1 with the HDTP models, you know how bad decent models look with that. But, overall, I enjoyed Invisible War in spite of its flaws. It's the last game made by the original DX crew, and it's definitely got the same spirit as the first, and is quite fun even if it was cut down. You can do much worse for games, hell, you can do much worse for Deus Ex games than Invisible War, and I'd say it's at least worth one go through for you to decide for yourself if this really is the worst DX game like everyone says it is.

content:
ber 8, 2016
												Granted, the maps are small, the UI is odd, and the game does NOT look like the screenshots in the steam store (must be screenshots of a mod or something), but Deus Ex: Invisible war, is overall a good game. The game needed 5 minutes of work after it was installed on my Windows 10, i7, gtx1080, but I solved the problem I had (where game was always in window mode but not filling the whole screen since I kept seeing my desktop which was annoying) by selecting the second highest resolution in the graphics options and that solved the issue for good. Since then I had no issues. Each time the game loads however your screen flickers around as if you would crash back to desktop, but the game each time gets a grip of itself and the map still loads normally, thus, I so far did not even have one game crash, as it runs smooth and stable.The graphics are very good for a game of that time period, but be aware, this is a much more simplified version from Deus Ex. No more manual input of codes, no more lock picks (multitool does all), no more different ammo types, as MAKO is the only weapons manufacturer which all require the same ammo type (whether a pistol or a rocket launcher). The voice acting also had a bit of a downgrade compared to its predecessor, so let's say the predecessor was a 10, this here would be a 7. For instance, when you traveled to Hong Kong in the predecessor, all NPCs spoke English with a Chinese accent, but this time when you go to Germany or Egypt, most still speak with American accents but there are NPCs that speak English with Arabic or German accents as well. If such minor details do not concern you, you will still love the voice acting. If you play as a male (Alex Denton), your voice seems very tired, which can be a bit frustrating, but then again, the rest of the voice acting is still top notch for today's standards! Graphics as mentioned before are good. But too bad no more in-game animations like in Deus Ex, where you could see your chopper fly off. Another minor detail but I believe it added a lot of quality to a game for its time, and now it is gone. You just click your aerial transport (Jet or Helicopter, you pick your pilot!) and that is all. Then again, each pilot drops you off in different locations, which was kind of neat, but then again, with the maps so small it won't really matter.Weapon controls. This is a bit of a disappointment. It is extremely easy to kill now as compared to the predecessor, and another downside is that they completely removed the skill system, so you have the same shooting abilities from the start to the end of the game. Also, you carry much fewer mods than before, and upgrading your mods is extremely easy, so you are already at max strength before even reaching mid-game. If that is good or bad, you tell me, but I liked it better when I used to be JC.tl;dr:Pros:+ Continous great storyline right after where the predecessor ended (Key point in Deus Ex universe!!!)+ Still pretty good voice acting overall+ Some nice locations!+ Fun side quests+ You can sometimes make some funny choices!!+ Sound in the night clubs! Real Band known as "Kidney thieves". Good stuff!+ Plenty hours of gameplay for the price.Cons:- Apparently unstable in many systems. Took me 5 mins for it to work well, others apparently need more time.- Small maps.- Simplified weapon usage- no skills, no lockpicks, multi tool does all now. - Overall simplified game from its predecessor. - Much more linear gameplay than predecessor.- Less Augmentations and augmentations very easily upgradeable (simplifying game).- Less in-game notes (less newspapers, books, texts, logs, screenshots, etc. In Deus Ex you really felt the conspiracy, here not as much).My advice:If you just just got into Human Revolutions and then Mankind Divided and find yourself intrigued by the Deus Ex story, then pick up Deus Ex GOTY edition which runs smooth, enjoy that amazing classic, and then afterwards, play through this game as well. Both are worth the money and the first Deus Ex has probably the best replay value for any Single Player game of all time, I play it once a year since 15 years and each time still encounter new hidden areas and locations and outcomes!!! It is incredible!

er 29, 2012
												The good news is that the writing and voice acting are both very good. The bad news is that the levels are all wildly cramped and the graphics look awful because the textures are low-resolution. Both are casualties of some idiot having demanded that this game should be ported to the original XBox, which had approximately zero bytes of RAM in it.The graphics look good again once you install the freely-available fan-made high-res texture packs, so that's fine. The cramped levels aren't really problematic any more, because Moore's Law has contracted the load times between levels to almost nothing. So in practice, this is a pretty fun game now, with branching plot lines and relatable characters - even though it was difficult to play and heinous to look at upon the day of its original release.

content:
3, 2016
												Deus Ex: Invisible War is a fun game, and it stays true to most of the things that made Deus Ex so incredible; however, it seems to be an overall downgrade. Here is a list of some of Deus Ex: Invisible War's major shortcomings compared to it's predecessor:-The loading times are much more severe-The levels are less open and feel more like a series of long hallways than an open map-Important statistics for various items and abilities that used to be displayed in the menus are no longer viewable, which harms the RPG aspect of the game significantly-The upgrade systems for weapons, biomods, and your character in general have been harshly simplified and minimalized so that they now lack many of what I considered to be essential aspects of the first Deus Ex-The game has a lot of bugs that make it difficult to play, whereas the first Deus Ex game was relatively glitch free-The game no longer features equipment (which, granted, felt relatively useless for most play-styles)-The notes and various acquired data is less detailed and less diverse; I frequently come across duplicate datapads and books, whereas every datapad and book in the original Deus Ex was unique-You can no longer assign custom keys for biomods or quick save/load, which is surprisingly tedious in the middle of combat when I have to hit “fn + f6” just to activate my enhanced speed mod, when I’d much rather hit “v” like I could in the first Deus Ex game-Acquired data, passwords, and passcodes are no longer saved and viewable at any time. Additionally, passwords and passcodes are no longer managed by a player, and the player never has to enter or remember passwords or passcodes in the game. This especially bothers me, because having to manage passwords on your own made hacking feel more like actual hacking, like an achievement of the player. I’d always find myself searching a room for clues as to what a password might be, which felt cool, but I never do that in Deus Ex Invisible War.-You get so much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ money within the first 5th of the game that it loses it’s value. Every other mission or “quest” in the game gives you money, and your rarely use it.There were some improvements, however. that Deus Ex: Invisible War made to the original game:-The stealth system is more complex and requires more strategy than the first Deus Ex-There were many new and interesting weapons and biomods, which give the player even more gameplay options, many of which were very fun to play around with-The game utilizes factions and loyalty systems to add a level of depth to the RPG experience-The graphics, obviously, are much better-The ragdoll physics are really cool, and they make moving bodies way more fun-The game allows you to play as a female, which is nice-The characters are slightly more developed, though completely static (as in the first game)-I imagine that for most people, it’s actually very convenient not having to manage passcodes and passwords themselves-The narrative in Invisible War is a bit better and more central to the game. In the original Deus Ex, I remember the story being very rough, and the characters to flat to care about. The narrative isn’t great in Invisible War, but it is an improvement.That was, of course, just a brief list of changes made between Deus Ex 1 and Deus Ex: Invisible War. Even that, however, is likely more information than necessary. In all honesty, there are only a few things to consider if you’re thinking about buying this game: did you really enjoy the original Deus Ex? If the answer is yes, than you should buy this game. As a fan of the first Deus Ex, I thoroughly enjoyed Deus Ex: Invisible War. I would say that the original Deus Ex was better, but Invisible War is still a good sequel that does not betray the aspects that made the original so good.Overal Score = 6.3/10 (Good, but nothing special)

content:
, 2016
												Invisible War is a decent game and a great sucessor to Deus Ex. I say that as someone who loves DX (and not Invisible War as much). I really like all three Deus Ex games. Yet after playing through Human Revolution I don't really appreciate the DX any more than when I started. But, revisiting DX after playing IW really did make me appreciate Deus Ex more, because certain characters, and their motivations, are well fleshed out in IW. And these motivations are closely related to your expereiences from DX. IW streamlines the DX experience. The original DX had a problem in that the hub worlds were a slog to get through, yet that slog made the exploration more worthwhile. In later stages of DX, the slog was removed but levels were no longer so open, and you weren't as engaged in your exploration.Invisible War has more clausterphobic levels throughout the course of the game, in part because of all the clunky reloading, but also because the spaces are smaller. Yet, the choices you have, the elements you can interact with, in all levels of IW (save the last, terrible level, which is spatially more open, yet empty as a vacuum), are as dense as the early levels of DX without being a slog.IW's story is much more focused than DX, because IW really focuses on a single idea (divisive politics). For example, the false struggle between coffee shops subversively highlights a major plot point and theme of the game; the triad war from DX almost serves a similar role, but the fact you clearly side with one "good" side kind of undermines this thematically.

content:
ry 19
												The invisible game that some people insist doesn't exist, despite it being better than some of the major titles released in the past year or so. As others have stated, this game would probably have a much bigger fanbase if it simply didn't have "Deus Ex" in the title.Deus Ex: Invisible War is a sequel to the original Deus Ex, taking place 20 years after a combination of all three of the original game's endings. The world has suffered from "The Collapse", where all global communication was shut down due to what happened in Area 51 at the end of Deus Ex. In the aftermath, the WTO and the Order helped the world recover. But the conspiracies of those who would control the fate of the world--and humanity--didn't end at Area 51. After a terrorist attack that destroys Chicago, the player is put into the shoes of a biomodified agent-in-training that discovers the truth behind the governments and organizations that run the world in 2072.As one might expect from how many Deus Ex fans pretend the game doesn't exist, there are a few flaws with Invisible War. Said flaws are important to know in advance to give a proper framework for enjoying the game. One of the big ones is that the game was designed specifically to run on the original Xbox as well as the PC, which means that it doesn't always play nice with modern (Windows 7 and onward) PCs and doesn't make use of multiple CPU cores. This also reflects in the level design, which cuts up some areas into smaller sub-areas with loading screens. The Xbox platform also ended up causing a simplification of the interface, which can go a little too far in some cases (such as the low number of potential keybinds).Another issue with the game, which it shares with the original game, is the blandness of the voice acting. Aside from the voice-modulated Omar cyborgs, a lot of characters sound more like students reading lines from a textbook than characters in a conspiracy thriller. Sometimes it was intentional or justified (such as JC's monotone in both games, which has reasons that the developers have stated), but most of the time you'll have to add inflection mentally to really get into the story.On the good side of things, Invisible War allows the same kind of emergent solution-finding as any other Deus Ex game. If you really try, you can play the game in almost any way you want. With the right gear and biomods, you'll almost always have at least two ways to accomplish an objective (and you'll probably have an alternate objective that still continues the story). Stealth, combat (lethal or non-lethal), diplomacy, hacking, lockpicking, and vent-crawling are all encouraged. There are a few overpowered builds (such as melee strength + stealth + baton for near-instant KOs of unarmored human enemies), but almost every option has at least some use. And unlike some games, you'll get more than enough upgrade points to upgrade every biomod, and you have the ability to swap out biomods if you don't like them (at the cost of losing the spent points in the rejected mod). So if you regret your choice in biomods, you don't always have to start over to try again.The story is much shorter than the original game and Human Revolution, clocking in at about 10 hours if you do ~90% of the content. However, there are enough alternate scenes and objectives that it can be worth replaying if a single playthrough isn't enough. The story itself is decent as a more sci-fi followup to the ending of Deus Ex, but there are some important characters that don't get enough development or screentime and the pacing ramps up a bit too quickly near the end (and leads to an area with so many enemies that some playstyles will be extra difficult at the end). The final choices in the last location are interesting from a philosophical standpoint, but the endings don't seem to fully develop these ideas (many of which were better handled in the ending monologues of Human Revolution).All in all, it is a good game that gets more bad press than it deserves. It won't ever be able to step out of the shadow of the original Deus Ex or the more recent revival prequels, but it's still a good diversion for those who enjoy cyberpunk games that allow for the freedom of problem-solving that Deus Ex is known for.

content:
ry 6, 2016
												This game is far from bad. I got carried away by the negative reception, and just pospone my playthough of this game, and even to the point that it affect my first impressions, I couldn´t stand this game at first. with that out of the way, I´ll start with the bad, and the things that most people are right, this game is a technical mess, it will crash, the game takes you to desktop just to load the next area, and the level are just too small.It really feels claustrophobic, it still have the same freedom of choice and consequences as the original Deus Ex have, but it really feels so small, in my opinion, compare to the big buildings and places of the original, also I dind´t like the simplification of the RPG mechanics and shooting, yes now where you point the gun shoot, but that doesn´t mean the gunplay is better (personally I like the way the first did it, it make you actually think ahead, instead as just go all guns blazing, as I did a lot here). As for the RPG mechanics, there almost non, they just kept the biomod upgrade system and they dumb it down, like real bad, it have a few good Ideas that make you prioritize your character but compered to the original, I dind´t feel like a badass cyborg this time, only a cyborg. So, why I recommend this game them? Still Deus Ex, Still fun, the story is really good and still the same cyberpunk conspiracy cyborg simulator that I love the first time, I this game make me crack out of laughter and make me high five myself more than onces by doing awesome deeds, and still a Role Playing game at hearth, you really play what you build... on my first run I build a Hacker, and no terminal was beyond my reach, and on the next playthourgh I was a cyborg assasin that was a ghost until it got to kill what it got to kill. And for the story, if there´s a reason to play this game, after the original is the way the game expand on the idiologies of the first game, I would say the way the game make take a choice It will feel overwhelming at first, but at the same time, that´s how your character have to feel. Also the game make use of returning character like I haven´t seen, it really feel like a justify sequel and it really expand of the deus Mythos, the endings tend to go in the absolute route, but at the same time, I though the same about the endings of the first deus ex, and some how the manage to make all three endings canon to this story. I haven´t played yet Human Revolution, but so far Deus Ex: The Fall is the worst game in the franchise, this one just blows it out of the water, and so far this is becoming my favorite videogame franchise of all time.

content:
r 20, 2016
												The story is more immersive than the first game and the missions seem more integral (at least the early missions). The graphics are also significantly better.However... Load times are quite lengthyEvery aspect of the gameplay seems less involved/simplified and for the most part it is bad.    - No leaning from cover.    - No need to stack boxes to get up the fire escape.    - Very few conversation choices this time around.    - You can not directly interface with keypads.    -  Computer terminals no longer exist (security consoles to).    - There is no skill leveling system (Infact that entire aspect of play is gone; you rely entirely upon the biomods you          choose. For example, you need to build for stealth because crouching is still noisy as hell).    - The info hub is so basic it might as well not exist.    - Inventory management is less interesting.    - Some biomods are completely useless, even going in guns blazing, the grenade premature-detonation mod is        negated by moving around.Despite all of this, it is still a good game and worth it for the story.

												The invisible game that some people insist doesn't exist, despite it being better than some of the major titles released in the past year or so. As others have stated, this game would probably have a much bigger fanbase if it simply didn't have "Deus Ex" in the title.Deus Ex: Invisible War is a sequel to the original Deus Ex, taking place 20 years after a combination of all three of the original game's endings. The world has suffered from "The Collapse", where all global communication was shut down due to what happened in Area 51 at the end of Deus Ex. In the aftermath, the WTO and the Order helped the world recover. But the conspiracies of those who would control the fate of the world--and humanity--didn't end at Area 51. One of the big ones is that the game was designed specifically to run on the original Xbox as well as the PC, which means that it doesn't always play nice with modern (Windows 7 and onward) PCs and doesn't make use of multiple CPU cores. This also reflects in the level design, which cuts up some areas into smaller sub-areas with loading screens. The Xbox platform also ended up causing a simplification of the interface, which can go a little too far in some cases (such as the low number of potential keybinds).Another issue with the game, which it shares with the original game, is the blandness of the voice acting. Aside from the voice-modulated Omar cyborgs, a lot of characters sound more like students reading lines from a textbook than characters in a conspiracy thriller. If you really try, you can play the game in almost any way you want. With the right gear and biomods, you'll almost always have at least two ways to accomplish an objective (and you'll probably have an alternate objective that still continues the story). Stealth, combat (lethal or non-lethal), diplomacy, hacking, lockpicking, and vent-crawling are all encouraged. There are a few overpowered builds (such as melee strength + stealth + baton for near-instant KOs of unarmored human enemies), but almost every option has at least some use. And unlike some games, you'll get more than enough upgrade points to upgrade every biomod, and you have the ability to swap out biomods if you don't like them (at the cost of losing the spent points in the rejected mod). So if you regret your choice in biomods, you don't always have to start over to try again.The story is much shorter than the original game and Human Revolution, clocking in at about 10 hours if you do ~90% of the content. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 17, 2014
												Video game sequels are pretty serious business. Although the sequel has become popular in nearly all forms of media, gaming is clearly one arena where its reigned supreme. In 2013, only 6 of the top 100 best selling games were entirely original works. Even critics in 2013 showed a preference towards established properties with only five original games scoring over 90 on MetaCritic. As such, there’s a great deal of pressure on developers to match, if not exceed, their previous work, and when a game’s considered a masterpiece, the expectations are magnified even further.As such, it’s no wonder that a game like Deus Ex: Invisible War has been so reviled by fans of the initial game, and many of the complaints are difficult to refute. Deus Ex has become one of my personal favorite games, and after having spent some time with War, I must concur with the majority that the first installment is a more complex and smarter game with vastly greater possibilities, but that’s not to say that this sequel has no charms or is inferior to most.The most marked change to the game’s core play is the removal of the skills system, which had allowed gamers to customize their play style in drastic ways, giving the cyberpunk shooter a distinct RPG flavor. Invisible War still contains RPG elements, primarily in the dialogue options and in the inclusion of Biomod super powers, but even these seem less malleable than before. Thus it plays in a much more straightforward way. There usually are still several ways to get through an area, but there are fewer times in which creativity is profitable.Level design philosophy has also shifted in major ways. The areas the player explores are significantly smaller and more straightforward, which results in a much greater amount of loading screens. This design choice was obviously made to make the console porting process smooth, but for what it’s worth, they cram an awful lot into these areas. In the first game, the areas may have been large, but some of them were mostly empty. The reverse is true in Invisible War with almost none of the filler, inaccessible background areas that plagued the cities we explored in Deus Ex.Whether this is a welcome change or not could be debated, because it does make it easier to find relevant destinations and exploration was a major draw of the first game, but were this an entirely new game, I would likely think nothing of this decision, and the same could be said for many of the games ‘flaws.’ Take the oft-criticized universal ammo approach. While the ammo can be used in any weapon, each weapon uses a different amount of ammo. I found myself favoring the sniper rifle for it’s accuracy and power, but this came at the cost of conservation, especially later in the game. Though most of the enemies drop ammunition, their clips do not cover the cost of a sniper shot, adding a strategic element that was lacking in the first game with its plentiful resources. Along with this the player has a smaller inventory, making management essential, serving as a stark counter to the comically large selection of weapons a player could carry in the first.Besides these controversial elements, the game is a major improvement in several areas. Even on release, Deus Ex was criticized for its bland art design and blocky textures, and the years have not done it a favor. Some of this blandness may have been to emphasize the destitute state of the poor, but that could also be a convenient excuse. Invisible War, however, has a vibrancy to it and is fairly detailed in spite of its age of over a decade. The difference in graphics becomes especially noticeable when comparing objects that appear in both games, such as the repair bot, which sports greater detail here but is instantly recognizable. The backgrounds are also better, effectively nailing the dystopian future.It’s the storytelling where the game really excels over its predecessor, though. The first game had plenty of interesting political and philosophical ideas, but since it was a longer game, the plot could get rather convoluted. It also featured rather poor dialogue and voice acting, although it could be humorous at times and sometimes even intentionally so. Though this game lacks some of those campy bits of fun, the writing feels a lot more professional and the story is concise enough that every section feels important, and it does this without losing the core debate between utility and freedom that was waged in the first game. The voice acting also has been given a boost. A few of the foreign accents are just as bad as in the first game, but the principle cast has been improved with a few small cameos from the first game thrown in for good measure.Along with these upgrades, the approach towards female characters is also laudable, particularly for its time. The first Deus Ex was smart, but it was a game dominated by men with most of the female characters playing in menial, background roles such as secretaries and receptions or in less flattering positions like hostage and muggee. Here, there seems to have been a very conscious decision to level the playing field. Besides letting you choose the protagonist Alex D’s race and gender, there are plenty of female enemies, and the majority of the figures that you encounter through the game from the pop star NG Resonance to your teacher Dr. Nassif to your classmates Billie and Klara to a potential pilot are women, and all of these figures are powerful in some ways or other. Although this sort of thing is much more common these days, it wasn’t the case in 2003, and I would bet that the game’s clear feminism has not received its due praise.Whether Deus Ex Invisible War is a good sequel is hard to say. It loses some of the things that made the first game such a joy to play and doesn’t necessarily subtract for the sake of its strengths. When looking at the sequel to such a popular game, though, the more pertinent question might be whether it is simply a good game or not, and to that the answer is a definite yes. It may streamline much of what made its predecessor good to such an extent that it becomes barely recognizable, but after all, when it comes to a sequel, who really needs or wants a carbon copy? Invisible War makes a number of bold changes that don’t always pay off, but it’s a must play for fans of Action RPGs and 1st Person Shooters.

												Come on, it's not that bad.  Not every game can be Deus Ex.  Only one game *is* Deus Ex.  Yes, they don't seem to have thought the world out properly.  Yes the game ends suddenly.  Yes it was buggy and (at first) needlessly resource-hungry.  But if this game had been called anything else you'd have thought it was a fun shooter with good atmosphere, diverse locations and an engaging plot - with a few merest hints of an RPG dotted through it for fun.  You should still play it, and you'll enjoy it.

												There isn't much entertainment from this game no matter which strategy you use. Go in guns blazing and, being the cyborg hero, chances are there is no challenge. Using stealth is tedious as the sophistication doesn't go any further than 'you can walk to point B from point A, or you can use the trusty air vent, not that it really matters which you choose'. The game in general lacks action, which itself isn't necessarily a criticism, but the environments and locations are bland (plus the graphics are a decade old) and the script is boring and delivery lifeless.Back in the days when I was a kid and a game was a rare commodity, I would plough through this anyway as it's not BAD, but an adult with a choice of hundreds of thousands of games from decades past to play, there's no point forcing it when I (and you if you feel the same about this or any other game) could be playing something entertaining or amazing instead.

content:
r 14, 2013
												This game is the very definition of the word "consolized". Compared to its predecessor it has smaller and more linear levels, simplified inventory, simplified damage model, fewer weapon mods, fewer tools, fewer augmentations, the skill system is gone, the unified ammo is an outright offense (but rationalized within the game world), and the gameplay feels much more linear without the decisions that had long-lasting consequences in the first Deus Ex. Yet, it's still a good game that's worth playing, and it's definitely better than Human Revolution -- for instance the story makes sense here, the dialogs are good and the game mechanics are not completely broken. I found it very interesting that most of the important figures in the game are female, including the protagonist by default. Make sure that you install the community-made high resolution texture pack.

content:
8, 2014
												A mess. A paltry mess!Invisible War could have been so much more. Why this game happened however, and why people thought it was a good idea, are the questions I pose. How could anything possibly follow Deus Ex? It is an utter impossibility for a game often tipped as game of the century. Furthermore, Deus Ex ends with 3 possible endings, and while Invisible War tries hard to tie these three endings together, it does not give the game full justice I feel as the plot feels incomplete. Characters from the first game are dragged back in for cameo roles, and this just feels redundant. Moreover to be questioned is which developer of the game decided to use generalised ammo throughout the game - I could garrote them for that move. I kid you not, I am unable to complete the game with ammunition without entering system files before playing and multiplying ammunition found in the world to 7 TIMES THEIR VALUE. Anything less, and I spend the last few levels of the game running around like a maniac because I have no ammunition at all, and the enemies later on require a lot to kill, and they drop so little ammunition! It just doesn't add up. The game also lacks the choice and diversity that Deus Ex so proudly boasted, and generally falls short in any respect I can think of.It is understandable as to why so many die-hard Deus Ex fans do not count this game as being canon whatsoever.

, 2011
												That IW is a colossal step down I won't deny.  The two biggest pains in the patoot being the tiny-as-fudgeknuckle box-shaped locations to explore providing far too many visits to the often broken loading screen and the writing itself heading into the fantastical, away from the recognizable and richly-detailed world of the first DX (gone are all the e-mails and most literature and admirable characters--& Pacotti/Grossman's high-quality dialogue with Australian-Chinese bartenders and hidden AI prototypes are limited to just a few instances like with the NG Resonance AI).  BUT: The game's still addictive; the story's stil strong enough to draw you in, and some levels, most notably the Egyptian arcology, are top notch (if you look past the loading screens); the goofy physics of objects and ragdolls are fun to mess around with; the graphics have held up well; and it's beyond satisfying to snoop around and knock out 2-dimensional villains with one baton swing to the face.

content:
6, 2016
												There are very few examples of a sequel in any medium being better than the original in the series. This is no exception to that.Now that I've gotten that out of the way, I'm going to do something a little different than what other reviewers do and repeat what I did with the Duke Nukem Forever review. Instead of pointing out the postivies and negatives, I'm going to say that my opinion is more valid than yours and that most of the negatives I see are either non existent or actually positives.1. The combat is clunky.I don't understand this complaint. I played it on the XBox and it was terrible on that system, yeah. But on the PC? It really isn't that terrible and it's more than managable. I think maybe the reason for this is people were playing this like they played the original Deus Ex. In the first game when you first started you sucked with every single ranged weapon ever and had to aim your gun for like 30 minutes before you could actually hit somebody. What I assume is happening is people are doing that in this game, and you really don't need to do that because you actually know how to use a firearm. I'd actually go as far as saying that makes the combat in this game better than in the first game. For some reason, in Deus Ex a highly trained cybernetic special forces operative has no idea how to use a basic handgun.2. It was dumbed down for consoles.Well, yes and no. First off, the original Deus Ex engine was basically a bunch of PVC pipes and calculators glued together. It was very simple and didn't eat up a lot of hardware so you could put a crapload of ♥♥♥♥ in the game and not worry about running out of space on the install disk along with not worrying about overworking the system memory. This game uses a (for the time) modern next gen engine with (for the time) amazing graphics and effects and stuff, not to mention a (for the time) decent physics engine as well. The short length and small size of levels allowed this to be put on XBox, yeah, but it also made it so we wouldn't have to use like 20 discs on PC. Sure, it would have been cool for the game to be the size of the original and use 20 discs, but come on.3. The story is dumb.I agree to some extent. The game is short, and since it's a Deus Ex game there's a plot twist like every 10 minutes so I can't really say much without spoiling like 35% of the story. Basically, at one point in the game you get two huge plot twists at the same exact time, and both of them got completely different reactions from me. The first one I saw coming from a mile away and was so obvious I could have sworn was already mentioned like two hours earlier or something. The second one I didn't see coming from a mile away but felt like a total idiot because I didn't in that it was completely logical. Sudden plot twists, especially of this caliber, are rarely done in such a way that it seems like the perfect conclusion to every single event that preceded. While elements of the story are really, REALLY stupid, for the most part it's very well written and worth your time.4. Too many RPG elements were removed/Character progression is gimped too much.I disagree here in that I like to play both of these games when I have completely different mindsets. If I want to play System Shock 1 or 2 but without horror elements I'll play the original Deus Ex, and if I want to play Bioshock 1 or 2 without the horror elements I'll play this. In my opinion, just because a sequel is different, doesn't mean it's bad.5. There's no multiplayer.Yes. This is a complaint I've seen people actually make. The original Deus Ex actually had deathmatch multiplayer for some really stupid reason that nobody but total nerds actually played. My guess is this was just one more feature they could complain about being removed from the game so they'd have another bullet to put in IW's skull.Overall, I give this game 8 out of 10, Deus Ex 9 out of 10 and Deus Ex: HR 8.5 out of 10.
