												Deus Ex Invisible War, being a straight sequel to Deus Ex, is left in a no win situation story wise. The multiple endings of Deus Ex 1 are retconned into being the same story 20 years in the future, cheapening your choices in the first game. IW also lacks the great writing that catagorized Deus Ex , reducing the series into mindless hollywood drivel. The game has an extremely weak third act, where the poor writing comes to a head.Gameplay wise, it's pretty much what you would expect from a generic action RPG. In some ways it's superior to Deus Ex, but it is highly casualized comparitively. In short, I would give this one a miss, even if you liked Deus Ex. This games' disrespect for the preceding story is a real turn off. Only play it if you really have a desire for a boring story and unlikable characters I guess.

												Oh, if only the rest of the Deus Ex series were as good as this one.The story is short -- maybe only 10-14 hours of gameplay -- and some of it can be repetitive. content:
ber 8, 2016
												I know this will say I've only put in point-whatever number of hours into this game, but that's somewhat inaccurate. I've been trying to force myself to play through this game since about 2007 on multiple computers and the original Xbox... and I just can't do it.  To me, it looks worse, runs worse, and feels worse than its predecessor.Yes, I'd rather play through the original Deus Ex with its stiff, robotic character animations and relatively simplistic engine than this bloated, compartmentalized, rushed-out cash-grab of a game.There is nothing about Invisible War that isn't disappointing.  The HUD is atrocious and obtrusive, the game engine is obviously the same one Ion Storm used for the (equally disappointing) Thief: Deadly Shadows... complete with floppy bodies and almost nonexistant light sources (did it really need to be this dark EVERYWHERE?), there's universal ammo, switching weapons and items is a chore, there's no character customization beyond biomods (of which you can only have up to five TOTAL - yes, you read that right), skills are gone, and with them, any reason to play this game as anything other than an action FPS (non-lethal is pointless, exploration is pointless), your inventory is tiny, the plot is shamefully bad, the NPCs stare at you with these creepy, wide open, unblinking eyes (again, even with worse graphics, the original Deus Ex did it better), a lot of items in the environment lack even basic textures, and then there are the load times... THE LOAD TIMES!As Invisible War was developed concurrently with the Xbox version, it was built from the ground up with the Xbox in mind... which meant lots of tiny level segments with loads between each.  However, even on current hardware, this game takes forever to load.  I dread level transitions because of this.This game is pure amateur hour and, as I mentioned, feels rushed and unfinished.  Even for its time, this is just bad.  Thief: Deadly Shadows, which came out about the same time, was made by the same people, and used the same engine, is better and more polished than this (though strangely, it seems Ion Storm had a fixation on forcing the player to choose between multiple, one-dimensional factions during this period, much to the detriment of both games).So that's it.  I just can't force myself to try to play it anymore.  I'm done.  I'm not going to waste any more time on what will eventually be as much of a disappointment at the end as it was at the beginning.  It will forever be the black sheep of the Deus Ex universe (even with Square Enix at the helm of the series).  This is absolutely not a recommended game.  Play something - anything - else.  Hell, play the IOS games instead.  They can't be any worse than this.

content:
, 2014
												My personal favourite Deus Ex. It is a great underated gem. Did it level up to the hype? No to most. To me, i love the game despite its flaws. I can hear the fans yelling at me about that. I will give a basic opening to the story for you: "Deus Ex Invisible War is set 20 years after Deus Ex, and is about the actions of JC Denton in the first game, (using a combination of all three endings from the first game) and how they caused the world to go into a state of war and "economic depression". It is known as THE COLLAPSE. Many factions then became into power, including the WTO and THE ORDER. Chicago gets attacked at the beginning of the game, and that is where you, Alex D, and your friend Billie Adams and others get evacuated to another Tarsus place. That gets attacked too, and you begin by doing side quests and must choose which faction you want to go with. Let me start with my personal favourite things about this great piece of gaming:- The graphics are great. Even by todays standards. It has aged well. (Made in 2004, it looks better than games released today)- The characters are fine. Not amazing, but ok. - THE BIOMODS! The Biomods are great. They add special abilities to the player for a mild amount of time, such as Cloaking, Increased Walk/jump speed, Increased strength, just to name a  few. - The menu's. Something small, but i like them.- The  weapons are simple and good, and there is several new weapons. - I always love craking something open or taking over something with my trusty Multitools. - Many more little tiny things. Now the bad. - The ai is basic, not bad but somewhat mediocre. - Some characters are bland, the order asian chick is my prime example. - the biomods are somewhat simpler to the first game. - Very minor technical hiccups. -  THE LOADING TIMES. THEY ARE BAD, THAT IS PROBABLY THE WORST PART ABOUT THIS. THEY ARE NOT INSANE, BUT THEY ARE BAD. IN CONCLUSIONI freakin' love this game. I look past it's supposed 'SHI*TYNESS'. Back at its release it recieved good reviews, but today everyone hates it. I love it, quite a bit, it's Well worth the price if you like RPG / FPS / Story driven obscure gems. Scarcey Out.

content:
3, 2014
												As a sequel to the original Deus Ex, Invisible War is weak, being inferior in most aspects. The levels are much smaller, the the levelling system is massively neutered (you can only upgrade augments, as opposed to additional skills) combat is weaker in many ways.With that said however, Invisible War is actually a pretty good game when taken on its own merits. First off, the atmosphere is fantastic. Even though the worlds are way smaller than those of Deus Ex 1, Invisible war uses lighting, music, and visuals to great effect, resulting in a moody world that draws you in, despite being so far removed from anything in the real world. The art direction is really fantastic. Furthermore, the storyline is really interesting. It doesn't start out quite as compelling as the original, but it picks up quickly and has loads of great twists. There were lots of memorable characters, as is series tradition, and it's great to see what became of certain characters from the first game (although I didn't care for what they did with JC Denton). Also, the fact that this game essentially provides closure for the Deus Ex Universe makes it very much worth seeing the game through to the ending.One really interesting thing this game does that the first game didn't (and I'd even say Invisible War might be slightly better in this regard) is that you can actually choose which faction to work for during each mission. Invisible War carries on the first game's tradition of having your choices make a massive impact on how the story plays out (I've heard that your choice of character gender actually has an effect on some of what side-missions are available, but I haven't done a second playthrough so I'm not sure what extent this alters things to), and being able to choose who you work for brings this to a whole new level, as it lets you experience the story from different perspectives, and what you do at certain points in the game actually does effect which endings are available (as opposed to in the first and third game, where you essentially choose your ending at the last minute). How you interact with characters is key and your relationships with the characters can affect the gameplay in numerous ways. The dialogue plays out more naturally than in the first game (I do miss how all the random NPCs seemingly had PHD's in philosophy in the first game, as it was cheesy, but also really interesting and part of the original's charm) and the story covers some interesting topics. Interestingly, this game goes into a lot of the same pro-augmentation vs anti-augmentation debates that characters in Human Revolution had (this topic was in Deus Ex 1 a bit, but not to the extent of this game and HR), so it does seem to have at least had some influence on future installments of the series. Overall, the storyline is definitely a strong point, and worthy of the Deus Ex name.Now, about the gameplay. Yes, it isn't nearly as good as Deus Ex 1, but it's still better than many games. Whereas the original was an RPG played through the interface of a first person shooter, this game is more of a first-person shooter with light RPG elements. Overall the guns feel decent (although the pistol is pretty useless), but the melee attacks lack punch. You'll be progressing through a series of cramped, but surprisingly non-linear levels and are given the freedom to choose your objectives based on what faction you like. There are a surprising amount of side missions, and just like in the original game, you can opt to do a pacifist run. Your augmentations can let you do some crazy, almost game-breaking stuff (Bot Domination is particularly awesome. It lets you take control of enemy robots, and getting the jump on an enemy patrol who was hanging out with enemy robots is both awesome and hilarious), which can lead to some fun situations. Something that's interesting about how this game handles augments is that you can actually replace your augments with a different ones if you find yourself in a desperate situation where an augment you didn't choose would be helpful. This is a last-ditch strategy though, as the new augment starts out un-upgraded, so you'll usually have to carefully weigh your options. Unfortunately, the weight of this decision is lessened a great deal by the sheer abundance of upgrade cannisters in the game. By the time you finish, you'll probably have at least 10 or so extra cannisters laying around, meaning that if you swap augs for a situation, you can often easily swap back to what you had before and re-upgrade it to the maximum level. Swapping is still an interesting and useful mechanic, even though the abundance of upgrades hurts the design.The inventory system is a bit awkward. You can only carry somewhat small amount of things, which makes sense from the standpoint that the developers want you to pick and choose a playstyle, but gets frustrating when you just want to pick up a medkit and all of your slots are full. Not too bad, but it does add up over time. Furthermore, there's a bug where sometimes more than one of the same item won't stack, which is especially frustrating for the lockpick multitools, as some doors need a certain amount (so if a door needs four tools, and you have two stacks of two, it won't open), which is incredibly frustrating. The interface of it is also a bit clunky, being clearly designed for a gamepad. It's not offensively bad, but moving an item to be equipped is a bit tedious, as you can't click and drag. Instead, you click the space for the item you want to move, and then click which slot you want it to go to.The main flaw of the gameplay is the universal ammo system. Basically there's one type of ammo, and if you run out of it for one gun, you're out of luck for all of your guns. It's frustrating and you run out often, but there are some benefits. It does force you to use stealth in some places and it encourages an efficient style of play (always go for headshots if you can). It also leads to some tense situations (such as you versus 15 armored guys and some robots with little ammo) that force you to think way outside the box and come up with your own solutions to problems, and it was actually during these parts that the game felt the most like Deus Ex 1. Despite these interesting situations, Universal ammo is a pretty ham-handed way of of making these things happen, and the same effects could have been achieved in different ways with better design. For all the neat gameplay scenarios it causes, it also causes a noticeable amount of annoyance (although there's always some way out of your problem). The level design is solid (despite levels being really small) and it does encourage you to expore the environment. You still have multiple ways to do things and what you do has a fascinating imact on the story. The real problem with the levels is that they're split up into many separate maps, which means you'll be seeing loading screens a ton. This isn't too bad as today's computers can load things rather quickly, but for some reason the game minimizes to the desktop each time a map loads, and then goes back to normal once everything is up. This is jarring and does take you out of the game abit, so an actual loading screen would have been nice. The levels themseles are densly packed with detail, and there is a great variety to the environments you'll be in. Most levels have a nice kind of back and forth flow, almost reminiscent in some ways of the level design in an oldschool Doom game (in a good way). The game mostly takes place in interiors as opposed to the large outdoors environments of Deus Ex 1, but the levels aren't bad.Overall, Invisible War falls short in many areas, especially compared to the original Deus Ex, but taken on its own it is a very interesting game that's definitely worth playing. There are a lot of unique ideas, and even though they don't all pan out, it mostly falls on the "good" side of things. Recommended.

content:
, 2014
												My personal favourite Deus Ex. It is a great underated gem. Did it level up to the hype? No to most. To me, i love the game despite its flaws. I can hear the fans yelling at me about that. I will give a basic opening to the story for you: "Deus Ex Invisible War is set 20 years after Deus Ex, and is about the actions of JC Denton in the first game, (using a combination of all three endings from the first game) and how they caused the world to go into a state of war and "economic depression". It is known as THE COLLAPSE. Many factions then became into power, including the WTO and THE ORDER. Chicago gets attacked at the beginning of the game, and that is where you, Alex D, and your friend Billie Adams and others get evacuated to another Tarsus place. That gets attacked too, and you begin by doing side quests and must choose which faction you want to go with. Let me start with my personal favourite things about this great piece of gaming:- The graphics are great. Even by todays standards. It has aged well. (Made in 2004, it looks better than games released today)- The characters are fine. Not amazing, but ok. - THE BIOMODS! The Biomods are great. They add special abilities to the player for a mild amount of time, such as Cloaking, Increased Walk/jump speed, Increased strength, just to name a  few. - The menu's. Something small, but i like them.- The  weapons are simple and good, and there is several new weapons. - I always love craking something open or taking over something with my trusty Multitools. - Many more little tiny things. Now the bad. - The ai is basic, not bad but somewhat mediocre. - Some characters are bland, the order asian chick is my prime example. - the biomods are somewhat simpler to the first game. - Very minor technical hiccups. -  THE LOADING TIMES. THEY ARE BAD, THAT IS PROBABLY THE WORST PART ABOUT THIS. THEY ARE NOT INSANE, BUT THEY ARE BAD. IN CONCLUSIONI freakin' love this game. I look past it's supposed 'SHI*TYNESS'. Back at its release it recieved good reviews, but today everyone hates it. I love it, quite a bit, it's Well worth the price if you like RPG / FPS / Story driven obscure gems. Scarcey Out.

content:
3, 2014
												As a sequel to the original Deus Ex, Invisible War is weak, being inferior in most aspects. The levels are much smaller, the the levelling system is massively neutered (you can only upgrade augments, as opposed to additional skills) combat is weaker in many ways.With that said however, Invisible War is actually a pretty good game when taken on its own merits. First off, the atmosphere is fantastic. Even though the worlds are way smaller than those of Deus Ex 1, Invisible war uses lighting, music, and visuals to great effect, resulting in a moody world that draws you in, despite being so far removed from anything in the real world. The art direction is really fantastic. Furthermore, the storyline is really interesting. It doesn't start out quite as compelling as the original, but it picks up quickly and has loads of great twists. There were lots of memorable characters, as is series tradition, and it's great to see what became of certain characters from the first game (although I didn't care for what they did with JC Denton). Also, the fact that this game essentially provides closure for the Deus Ex Universe makes it very much worth seeing the game through to the ending.One really interesting thing this game does that the first game didn't (and I'd even say Invisible War might be slightly better in this regard) is that you can actually choose which faction to work for during each mission. Invisible War carries on the first game's tradition of having your choices make a massive impact on how the story plays out (I've heard that your choice of character gender actually has an effect on some of what side-missions are available, but I haven't done a second playthrough so I'm not sure what extent this alters things to), and being able to choose who you work for brings this to a whole new level, as it lets you experience the story from different perspectives, and what you do at certain points in the game actually does effect which endings are available (as opposed to in the first and third game, where you essentially choose your ending at the last minute). How you interact with characters is key and your relationships with the characters can affect the gameplay in numerous ways. The dialogue plays out more naturally than in the first game (I do miss how all the random NPCs seemingly had PHD's in philosophy in the first game, as it was cheesy, but also really interesting and part of the original's charm) and the story covers some interesting topics. Interestingly, this game goes into a lot of the same pro-augmentation vs anti-augmentation debates that characters in Human Revolution had (this topic was in Deus Ex 1 a bit, but not to the extent of this game and HR), so it does seem to have at least had some influence on future installments of the series. Overall, the storyline is definitely a strong point, and worthy of the Deus Ex name.Now, about the gameplay. Yes, it isn't nearly as good as Deus Ex 1, but it's still better than many games. Whereas the original was an RPG played through the interface of a first person shooter, this game is more of a first-person shooter with light RPG elements. Overall the guns feel decent (although the pistol is pretty useless), but the melee attacks lack punch. You'll be progressing through a series of cramped, but surprisingly non-linear levels and are given the freedom to choose your objectives based on what faction you like. There are a surprising amount of side missions, and just like in the original game, you can opt to do a pacifist run. Your augmentations can let you do some crazy, almost game-breaking stuff (Bot Domination is particularly awesome. It lets you take control of enemy robots, and getting the jump on an enemy patrol who was hanging out with enemy robots is both awesome and hilarious), which can lead to some fun situations. Something that's interesting about how this game handles augments is that you can actually replace your augments with a different ones if you find yourself in a desperate situation where an augment you didn't choose would be helpful. This is a last-ditch strategy though, as the new augment starts out un-upgraded, so you'll usually have to carefully weigh your options. Unfortunately, the weight of this decision is lessened a great deal by the sheer abundance of upgrade cannisters in the game. By the time you finish, you'll probably have at least 10 or so extra cannisters laying around, meaning that if you swap augs for a situation, you can often easily swap back to what you had before and re-upgrade it to the maximum level. Swapping is still an interesting and useful mechanic, even though the abundance of upgrades hurts the design.The inventory system is a bit awkward. You can only carry somewhat small amount of things, which makes sense from the standpoint that the developers want you to pick and choose a playstyle, but gets frustrating when you just want to pick up a medkit and all of your slots are full. Not too bad, but it does add up over time. Furthermore, there's a bug where sometimes more than one of the same item won't stack, which is especially frustrating for the lockpick multitools, as some doors need a certain amount (so if a door needs four tools, and you have two stacks of two, it won't open), which is incredibly frustrating. The interface of it is also a bit clunky, being clearly designed for a gamepad. It's not offensively bad, but moving an item to be equipped is a bit tedious, as you can't click and drag. Instead, you click the space for the item you want to move, and then click which slot you want it to go to.The main flaw of the gameplay is the universal ammo system. Basically there's one type of ammo, and if you run out of it for one gun, you're out of luck for all of your guns. It's frustrating and you run out often, but there are some benefits. It does force you to use stealth in some places and it encourages an efficient style of play (always go for headshots if you can). It also leads to some tense situations (such as you versus 15 armored guys and some robots with little ammo) that force you to think way outside the box and come up with your own solutions to problems, and it was actually during these parts that the game felt the most like Deus Ex 1. Despite these interesting situations, Universal ammo is a pretty ham-handed way of of making these things happen, and the same effects could have been achieved in different ways with better design. For all the neat gameplay scenarios it causes, it also causes a noticeable amount of annoyance (although there's always some way out of your problem). The level design is solid (despite levels being really small) and it does encourage you to expore the environment. You still have multiple ways to do things and what you do has a fascinating imact on the story. The real problem with the levels is that they're split up into many separate maps, which means you'll be seeing loading screens a ton. This isn't too bad as today's computers can load things rather quickly, but for some reason the game minimizes to the desktop each time a map loads, and then goes back to normal once everything is up. This is jarring and does take you out of the game abit, so an actual loading screen would have been nice. The levels themseles are densly packed with detail, and there is a great variety to the environments you'll be in. Most levels have a nice kind of back and forth flow, almost reminiscent in some ways of the level design in an oldschool Doom game (in a good way). The game mostly takes place in interiors as opposed to the large outdoors environments of Deus Ex 1, but the levels aren't bad.Overall, Invisible War falls short in many areas, especially compared to the original Deus Ex, but taken on its own it is a very interesting game that's definitely worth playing. There are a lot of unique ideas, and even though they don't all pan out, it mostly falls on the "good" side of things. Recommended.

content:
er 21, 2014
												Many people will say that this game is the worst.  "It's nothing like the first game!  It blows chunks!"Well, I'll say you're wrong.It is DEFINATELY not the best game in the series, like the first one.  Like Deus Ex: The Fall you need to look at the game as what they wanted it to be and how accutare the game got to their target.  As we can see in the ad for it, most of what is shown is firefights and explosions.  Perhaps they wanted a more action-esque game?  Yes and no.I know it says that I'm played very little of the game here on steam, however I had a CD copy of this recently and decided to play it one day as it had only been opened a few times before.  My older cousins would come once in a while and since we had a desktop, cousin P would come and play his collection of PC games he would leave here.  Recently, within the last few months in the smmer, I found the stash and this was in it.After 6 hours of playing it off the CD I can say, yes the game IS NOT the first one.  Most scenes are better done by running and gunning rather than slow and comprehensive plans and watching the walking patterns.  And sure, it might crash once in a blue moon; who cares!  This is a windows 2000 game :DOther than the main RPG flaw being that you need a gun no matter what to go anywhere fast, you can definately play the game the old style if you want to.  This does prove to be tougher over all as the enemies don't USUALLY walk on a path anymore.  Nor do the have a specific walk area.  Enemies tend to explore, and if they find you you're done unless you flatten them ASAP.  Armor is indeed hard to come by as an upgrade so it is worth having health items as often as possible.  You will take a hit, even it a random fire starts.Different from the first game, where in the beginning you have to collect items from enemy guards and such instead of finding them in random places, in this game it is flipped:  you can just find random whatever anywhere on the map.  As I said earlier the RPG elements are indeed lowered.So what were they aiming for?  While the first game revolutionized how we think of FPRPG's nowadays, at the time quake was the holyfartcow of the universe just as COD is now.  What was most likely being aimed for was the idea of being more like a shooter than an RPG, even though those elements are still there.  Not helpful in a stealth FPRPG.Overall score?  7.6 / 10.  Not a bad game, just not as good as the first.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This game surpassed my expecations. There is a surprisingly large amount of choices which have a real impact on the story. I found the story and side stories to be interesting and supportive of the gameplay. The gameplay itself is pretty damn fun and comparable to the first game, involving stealth, gunplay, tech equipment, special abilities, etc.I've beaten both the original Deus Ex and now Invisible War and I must say, besides the changes to streamline certain gameplay aspects, Invisible War is just as high quality as the first. It definitely seemed like a true sequel to me, despite what I've read online. And hell, I'd even say the changes make the game a lot easier to get a handle on, as the first game at times felt a bit overwhelming to deal with. I actually felt a lot more engaged with the biomod system in Invisible War because of the fact that it laid out the details more clearly. The main issue with this game is the loading screen issue. Levels are HEAVILY segmented into separate areas that must be loaded individually, and every time you enter a new area, the game minimizes for a few seconds, comes back up and then takes another few seconds to load. This process also occurs every time you load a save, meaning that even hitting quickload (F12) will force you to wait 10 seconds. The original game had instant quick loading, as MOST games do. If you are wondering if you should play this after playing the first game, then the answer is yes. Don't let whiny comments about the game being terrible because it was "consolized" fool you. This is a true, high quality sequel to the original Deus Ex.

content:
28, 2014
												Terrible sequel to the best single player game ever.. Where to begin.The AI is less intelligent than a wifi toaster. Sometimes it feels like they are inanimate objects. Your inventory is so limited, and in an obscure way (6+6 item slots no matter the size of the item, some stack, still annoying). Conversations are b-movie-esque, however there are some hidden gems in there.I thought the graphics were pretty good when I was a kid, probably the first dynamic shadows I remember seeing, but they weren't used to their potential at the time... and the low polycount on just about everything is kind if weird considering the sizes of the individual levels.Almost forgot the worst part of all, loading in this game is still slow mega years after release, and it still alt-tabs and switches resolution between gameplay and loading screen. Pretty sure this issue isn't just me, or maybe I'm crazy for thinking it happened the first time I played it too.There's some good story value, and some story branching (very little of consequence), and generally doesn't feel relative to the original other than the namethrowing. Not recomended unless you've played the first enough times to be the daedalus of its every pixel.

content:
2016
												Well I didn't end up playing the game for long before I uninstalled it and jumped onto the IW-hate bandwagon. I barely left the academy (first level) before I decided to not play this game again. As subjective as my opinion is, I cannot see any way of recommending people to put money into it; and I would be reluctant to even say 'go for it' if it was a free game out of fear I will create personal vendettas against me by wasting time.From the intro alone it has no Deus Ex feeling at all in my opinion; it looks less like a dystopian cyberpunk and more like a bad sci-fi that has none of the charm of the original Deus Ex, if you're pondering on trying the game because it has the name in the title, I recommend looking up the intro on youtube and ask yourself if it's still what you're hoping for.The second thing I noticed was how utterly difficult it was for me to even get the game to run at all because of the outdated engine that is damn near incompatiable with anything that has multi-cores (which is to say every modern computer) that made it a pain requiring me to down a few hours in searching for a fix online in various forums; which is already a major nono for anything that gets put on steam, if it's on a platform like Steam asking for money to play it, it should at the very least work by default.If anyone is interested, I'll leave the link that finally made the game run for everyone's convenience: http://yoni0505.blogspot.se/2012/08/deus-ex-invisible-war-windows-7-fix.htmlWith the game finally running and having recently finished the original Deus Ex (Revision), I was eager to try the game for myself and see the continuation of the previous game and what effects the events of it would have on the world of the sequel. I knew it was widely hated, but somehow the arguments never quite ran. Small levels and clunky UI sounded like something you could overcome if you were interested in the story, and I really wanted to explore Chicago and Seattle of the future. So the first thing I do is to set the keymapping to be more akin to the original Deus Ex's controls as much as possible for my own comfort and fixing the mouse sensitivity to be lower. Then I start the game.First I get that intro cutscene and realize that exploring Chicago is not really on the agenda here. Maybe I should've read into it more, but I guess it just gets destroyed in the cutscene and welcome to Seattle. Okay, fair enough I think.Then there is Seattle where I try to immerse myself and get comfortable with the controls before I get earthquakes shoved in my face; no time to rest there. When I get into my first conversation I experience a rarity for me: graphics cringe. I'm not one to typically care about graphics; I like the old styles such as the original ones over things like Crysis even, but ♥♥♥♥ me they couldn't have made a poorer job with these. This is without mentioning how lackluster and horribly paced the conversations are.Go to a let's play and check just the first conversation with Billie to determine it for yourself. If it becomes unbearable, save your money to something more productive. Maybe there's a hobo nearby who could use a cup of coffee for the dollar or whatever that Steam wants for the game.Anyway the next thing I notice is that the criticisms of small levels well, the fans were not exaggerating; imagine UNATCO HQ in the original game from the moment you step into the upper level where Manderley and your office etc is. Know how there is a lower level too? In IW, that lower level would be behind a loading screen; and the upper level doesn't contain the eye scanner or anything of the sort either. That should give an idea of how small the maps are, and I'm even unsure if that's an exaggeration.What kills it for me though is how a game riddled more loading screens than ♥♥♥♥♥ in an elephant's ♥♥♥ seem to have an unhealthy obsession with resetting everything upon a new loading screen; it's like the game restarts itself before the loading screen itself appears, and when it's done loading all the key mappings are reset and all the items- including weapons -are gone. This world of item-vaporizing elevators/doorways becomes especially bothersome if you wanna cap some heads, because good luck getting anything done in terms of combat if you don't have any weapons on you; and weapons aren't in a habit of just laying around everywhere either.At the final bit of the Seattle Tarsus Academy I just gave up and casually ran past everyone in full view, not even caring about getting shot twice or thrice (which took less than half my hp) and just kept going to see if I could at least get value out of seeing Upper Seattle. Some story blocks along the way I didn't care about later and I realized.. Pretty much no. The environment is stale and uninspired and conversations don't get anymore interesting from the three or so places in the level that had people. You get more character interaction and personality from a Choice of Games than what I got in Upper Seattle. And that's where I finally lost my last interest and justification for having spent any money on this even at a sale. The only thing I got from that money spent is buyer's remorse; but hey, at least the buyer's remorse is consistent unlike the ♥♥♥♥ing keymapping in IW.=TL;DR=I only played so much, but if you are interested in seeing this game then I would say don't waste your money on it; look up a let's play of someone else who wasted money on it instead and save yourself the effort. If it still looks appealing after an episode or two of said let's play; only then should it ever be considered.*Poor environments.*Poor voice acting and conversation pacing.*Poor graphics and character models.*No cyberpunk or Deus Ex feeling.*Difficult to run on a modern system and requires a lot of system ♥♥♥♥ery to at all get started.That's my experience after less than an hour with no real expectation going for it coming in; I should've listened.

ry 25, 2016
												I spent a long time not believing that this game could be that bad. I'd read countless reviews of how this game was a disappointment, tried to familiarize myself with its flaws without spoiling the story for myself, and made my decision: I would buy it when it went on crazy sale. $1.40 was sale enough for me. I don't regret the purchase, but I don't recommend the game, and the reasons are manifold.First, ignore any review that says "if this game weren't a Deus Ex game, it would be regarded better". No. Even ignoring the Deus Ex aspects, what you're left with is a ♥♥♥♥ poor shooter with a trashy story, ♥♥♥-ugly character models, glitchy gameplay, and poor mechanics choices. This game is both figuratively and literally a narrow hallway. Half of the time, you're dropped into an area that has little to no hiding spaces and relatively few alternate paths. What few areas do have alternate paths to your objective are circular and do a poor job of telegraphing that you're going backwards. The area maps are practically microscopic, and you're hard pressed to go even three minutes of normal gameplay without having to load up a new area. This makes exploring a chore, so after the first hour of gameplay I gave up and decided I would just plow through the story and get it over with. Also, just by the way, there's a glitch where the game crashes to the desktop or hangs on a black screen during every loading screen, and upon reaching the final area, it has crashed for me five times with no possible fix in sight. Just a heads up if you really want to try to see this through.So, let's talk about the story. Where Deus Ex was a political commentary through the eyes of a conspiracy theorist, Deus Ex: Invisible War is a sociopolitical commentary through the eyes of a gender studies major, and if I let my inner conspiracy theorist come forward, I might just have to say that this is one of the first games ruined by the thoughtless inclusion of female main characters for the sake of having more "gender diversity". Default avatar gender? Female. The Order? Female dominated. WTO? Majority female. Borderline genocidal maniacs/nazi looking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ templars? Male leader, almost completely male dominated organization.  All of that aside:You're cast into the world of Deus Ex: Invisible War by being treated to an uncanny valley cutscene the likes of which only 2003 CGI can produce. A faceless terrorist unleashes grey goo on Chicago and later you're told it was fire. That's all well and good though, because Chicago isn't important, you're in Seattle, in what is essentially a high school anime gone wrong. With no warning or buildup, the Tarsus academy is under attack by "the Order", a group of religious zealots who think jihad is the way to go. You can follow orders from these maniacs later, while their second in command tries to convince you that they are indeed a religion of peace by explicitly asking you to murder their targets. Conversely, you can do the bidding of the World Trade Organization, who sits comfortably at the other end of the spectrum at what seems to be Lawful Neutral at worst. Following orders from them doesn't always feel right, but it doesn't make you feel like a sociopath.It takes hours of gameplay to be drawn in even the smallest bit, and the writing never really recovers. Even the endings feel halfassed, though if you stew on them for long enough, they're just thought provoking enough to be worthy of discussion if you're bored.Overall, this game is bad. Not because it's an unworthy successor to much better game, but because it barely stands up as a game. It is nothing more than a seven hour long walking simulator with guns added here and there for flavor.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2011
												Deus Ex was a groundbreaking entry into the world of FPS and RPG. Some, such as myself, have praised the first installment as PC gaming's finest masterpiece. Needless to say, Invisible War (IW) had a lot to live up to. As a standalone product, IW is no doubt a competent competitor. However, as a sequel to a legendary franchise, it merely captures what made its predecessor remarkable, doing little to improve anything.Perhaps the most noticeable change in this game is its simplicity. The original Deus Ex offered an overwhelming amount of skills you could invest in, ranging from your weapon proficency to your augmentations. IW kept only the latter. While this made the game easier to comprehend and manage, it also drastically reduced the versatility so proudly flaunted by the first game.The AI devolved and bugs are aplenty. Fortunately, moral choices and combat approaches are still as open ended as ever and that, at its core, is what makes IW a great game.Grade: B+

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 25, 2011
												Was this game rightly panned? Yes. Is the engine terrible? Yes, with maps under half the size of its predecessor, and twice as crude, albeit with some very nice dynamic lights. Is the gameplay horrendously dumbed down and fundamentally broken in ways (in particularly the universal ammo)? Yes. Although despite losing lean keys, Alex gains the elusive ability to mantle, a welcome return from the SysShocks.Do you, just for a fleeting moment, sometimes get a little whiff of being an augmented agent preying on terrified goons? Yes, but then you hit a map load barrier. Does it undermine JC and sometimes venture too far into "look, look, a person from the previous game, love me!"? Unfortunately.But does it still have smart dialogue if you poke about? Yes. Does it have allegiances more complicated and subtle than "good" or "evil"? Yes, and more freedom than DX1. If you can get it stupid-cheap in a sale, is it worth putting up with the gameplay to weave yourself a plot?Probably.

content:
7, 2015
												I recommend this game if you can get it for at least 75% off! A steam sale will likely allow you to grab it even cheaper, and it's certainly worth a play. What's OK or good - story, robot enemy design, voice acting, genuinely different ways to do most things, the game rewards you for exploring, nice weapon sounds, good stealth sections, the odd genuinely amusing line (my favorite was the NG AI's reply to what she's gonna go about her manager), setting Templar bigots on fire from distance with the Hellfire Boltcaster. The game is pretty much worth it just for that last one. What's bad or terrible - It's a whole lot less fun than Human Revolution, the levels need to re-load very often due to the whole "aimed at consoles" thing, making the level management feel older than the smooth transitions of Half-Life, you can't sell things to traders, and there's not really a whole lot worth buying either, you need to have several saves because of the high chance of your latest one going kaput and refusing to load. It used to do that on Xbox too. Ahhh, Nostalgia. Can't take F12 screencaps either despite steam overlay claiming to work. That might just be my PC though.

content:
, 2013
												8/10.WOW!!! How many have missed an amazing game? I must admit I had serious trouble getting into this game, the training mission at the beginning is in need of refinement; It feels slow, clumsy, lazy, linear and I couldn’t work out how take all the inventory... but once you’re on the streets of Seattle the game comes into its own.I have my share of criticism... and I find the game has ‘bugs’ it’s hard to climb into some ducts and the autosave is GRRRR terrible. But the formula and implementation... make it a cracker of a game.While there are guns and goodies to add a bit of action this isn’t the best shooter game. I would describe the game more adventure than anything else. The difficult choices required to ‘save’ the world are much much later in the game, So once the hand holding at the beginning is over go out and turn the fractions on each other!My last line: A forgotten wonder? I really recommend the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
												Well I didn't end up playing the game for long before I uninstalled it and jumped onto the IW-hate bandwagon. I barely left the academy (first level) before I decided to not play this game again. As subjective as my opinion is, I cannot see any way of recommending people to put money into it; and I would be reluctant to even say 'go for it' if it was a free game out of fear I will create personal vendettas against me by wasting time.From the intro alone it has no Deus Ex feeling at all in my opinion; it looks less like a dystopian cyberpunk and more like a bad sci-fi that has none of the charm of the original Deus Ex, if you're pondering on trying the game because it has the name in the title, I recommend looking up the intro on youtube and ask yourself if it's still what you're hoping for.The second thing I noticed was how utterly difficult it was for me to even get the game to run at all because of the outdated engine that is damn near incompatiable with anything that has multi-cores (which is to say every modern computer) that made it a pain requiring me to down a few hours in searching for a fix online in various forums; which is already a major nono for anything that gets put on steam, if it's on a platform like Steam asking for money to play it, it should at the very least work by default.If anyone is interested, I'll leave the link that finally made the game run for everyone's convenience: http://yoni0505.blogspot.se/2012/08/deus-ex-invisible-war-windows-7-fix.htmlWith the game finally running and having recently finished the original Deus Ex (Revision), I was eager to try the game for myself and see the continuation of the previous game and what effects the events of it would have on the world of the sequel. I knew it was widely hated, but somehow the arguments never quite ran. Small levels and clunky UI sounded like something you could overcome if you were interested in the story, and I really wanted to explore Chicago and Seattle of the future. So the first thing I do is to set the keymapping to be more akin to the original Deus Ex's controls as much as possible for my own comfort and fixing the mouse sensitivity to be lower. Then I start the game.First I get that intro cutscene and realize that exploring Chicago is not really on the agenda here. Maybe I should've read into it more, but I guess it just gets destroyed in the cutscene and welcome to Seattle. Okay, fair enough I think.Then there is Seattle where I try to immerse myself and get comfortable with the controls before I get earthquakes shoved in my face; no time to rest there. When I get into my first conversation I experience a rarity for me: graphics cringe. I'm not one to typically care about graphics; I like the old styles such as the original ones over things like Crysis even, but ♥♥♥♥ me they couldn't have made a poorer job with these. This is without mentioning how lackluster and horribly paced the conversations are.Go to a let's play and check just the first conversation with Billie to determine it for yourself. If it becomes unbearable, save your money to something more productive. Maybe there's a hobo nearby who could use a cup of coffee for the dollar or whatever that Steam wants for the game.Anyway the next thing I notice is that the criticisms of small levels well, the fans were not exaggerating; imagine UNATCO HQ in the original game from the moment you step into the upper level where Manderley and your office etc is. Know how there is a lower level too? In IW, that lower level would be behind a loading screen; and the upper level doesn't contain the eye scanner or anything of the sort either. That should give an idea of how small the maps are, and I'm even unsure if that's an exaggeration.What kills it for me though is how a game riddled more loading screens than ♥♥♥♥♥ in an elephant's ♥♥♥ seem to have an unhealthy obsession with resetting everything upon a new loading screen; it's like the game restarts itself before the loading screen itself appears, and when it's done loading all the key mappings are reset and all the items- including weapons -are gone. This world of item-vaporizing elevators/doorways becomes especially bothersome if you wanna cap some heads, because good luck getting anything done in terms of combat if you don't have any weapons on you; and weapons aren't in a habit of just laying around everywhere either.At the final bit of the Seattle Tarsus Academy I just gave up and casually ran past everyone in full view, not even caring about getting shot twice or thrice (which took less than half my hp) and just kept going to see if I could at least get value out of seeing Upper Seattle. Some story blocks along the way I didn't care about later and I realized.. Pretty much no. The environment is stale and uninspired and conversations don't get anymore interesting from the three or so places in the level that had people. You get more character interaction and personality from a Choice of Games than what I got in Upper Seattle. And that's where I finally lost my last interest and justification for having spent any money on this even at a sale. The only thing I got from that money spent is buyer's remorse; but hey, at least the buyer's remorse is consistent unlike the ♥♥♥♥ing keymapping in IW.=TL;DR=I only played so much, but if you are interested in seeing this game then I would say don't waste your money on it; look up a let's play of someone else who wasted money on it instead and save yourself the effort. If it still looks appealing after an episode or two of said let's play; only then should it ever be considered.*Poor environments.*Poor voice acting and conversation pacing.*Poor graphics and character models.*No cyberpunk or Deus Ex feeling.*Difficult to run on a modern system and requires a lot of system ♥♥♥♥ery to at all get started.That's my experience after less than an hour with no real expectation going for it coming in; I should've listened.

												Not as horrible as I expected it to be considering all the hate it gets. But still pretty bad.The good stuff - there some interesting ideas here and there. Everyonce in a while the game manages to capture this Deus Ex feeling of finding alternative way to the objective or discovering a hidden stash. But......the levels are insultingly small.  I imagine it is an issue with the engine as Thief: Deadle Shadows suffered from similar problem. As the result levels are shallow and allow for very little freedom or experimentation.The story is fogettable. The gameplay play more like a bad shooter with light RPG elements than RPG with FPS perspective.In all, DE:IW is surrounded by better titles. If you want deep RPG check the original Deus Ex. If you want easier to get into, shinier and more action packed version try Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Both a superior titles to this one. And as IW doesn't add anything substantial to the franchise you can skip it.Also I completed it in 13 hour while checking every corner, vent and pit. Not much content. But in tis case it is probably a good thing.

content:
er 17, 2012
												Terrible combat, level design, story, game play and game design. Invisible War has nothing going for it and is completely forgettable console-pandering garbage. Stripped of RPG elements with a dumbed down inventory using universal ammo for all your guns, this game was really ahead of it's time in casualizing a well known game series for a "wider audience." Characters are simplistic, disposable, and forgettable; I couldn't tell you who is in this game besides JC, Adam, and Tracer Tong. The plot and all the new story elements introduced are poorly written and embarassing when placed next to its predecessor. It's a real shame that this black mark is on the series considering how amazing the original and Human Revolution are.

content:
y 16
												EDIT: I am so very, very happy to say that an unofficial patch for the game has FINALLY been released! I can now happily thumbs up the game with a decent recommendation. Made by the same guy who turned Thief Deadly Shadows into one of my favourite games, you can pickup this beautiful patch here: http://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-2-visible-upgradeThe original game is my favourite game of all time, so much so that I guess that you could call me one of them close-minded fanboys unwilling to accept criticism of it. I love that thing so much. But this isn't it.I have no idea how I have 30 hours. I must have left this open a few times, which I do a lot. It's more like 13 hours. Didn't get very far, and just kept restarting over and over here and there over a couple of years.Stealth seems to not work in the slightest. Other than that, gameplay doesn't feel near as good as the original game and I can't stand the shooting. Feels so clunky and the universal ammo is just something no matter how hard I try I can't get over. If this ever got a Sneaky Tweaker-esque patch for it, I would give it another shot though, but at the moment the technical issues are the dealbreaker. (EDIT: Technical issues are no longer an issue!)The Great:++Great graphics for 2004, even when compared to Half-Life 2 and DOOM 3++Passive augmentations are a very welcome addition++The main characters are pretty unique and well written for the most part The Good:+Art-style is appealing although it's much less cyberpunk and far more sci-fi so...+Side-quests are fun but...+Music is actually quite good but...+The endings are bleak and dark and are very well done+Sound-effects aren't anything amazing in terms of quality, but the sound themselves are unique and provide atmosphere wellThe Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:+-Side-quests end up being meaningless-+Weapons feel wonky and a bit like plastic toys+-The factions idea is good but could have been done far better-+Male protagonist voice-acting is lackingThe Bad:-Too sci-fi, going against the originals cyberpunk theme-Uninteresting side characters-Loading screens do suck big time-Small levels do suck big time-Crashes a lot on modern OS's (fixed with patch)-Not a fan of the illegal biomod concept-The level design is a lot more linear, probably due to smaller maps-Stealth is horrible, and it's not just meThe Horrible:--Music is far inferior to the original soundtrack, of which I consider to be my favourite in any game ever, due to it being far more ambience this time around--Absolutely dreadful performance. Ran at 50fps on a GTX750Ti at 1080p full shadows--The game is generally wonky as hell and hasn't aged well in some regards ((http://tinyurl.com/Death-By-Shower)--Universal ammo is almost a dealbreaker all by itselfSound: 7.5/10Graphics: 7.5/10 Gameplay: 8/10Content/Replayability: 8/10Overall: 8/10Will update review as I go because I've missed quite a bit.Can someone please just make a bloody patch for this game soon though please? I'll finally finish it if someone would. It's desperately in need of one.Game's not horrible, but it's too poor for it to be worth it. (EDIT: Someone made a patch!)The ratings ignore the performance issues.

												Not as horrible as I expected it to be considering all the hate it gets. But still pretty bad.The good stuff - there some interesting ideas here and there. If you want easier to get into, shinier and more action packed version try Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Both a superior titles to this one. And as IW doesn't add anything substantial to the franchise you can skip it.Also I completed it in 13 hour while checking every corner, vent and pit. Not much content. content:

												Was this game as bad as I'd heard, being a less-than stellar sequel to an amazing game?  God yes.  the AI is laughable, the story was pathetic, NONE of the endings seemed particularly appealing to me.  And all the nice choices and complexities of the first game were removed for a more streamlined, and thus utterly unrealistically easy performance.  The fact that you can counter security measures so easily just defeats the purpose.  Laser grids are massively exposed, glass can be disintegrated, robots can be turned to your side with a single sword strike.  The only reason enemies at the end were any sort of challenge is they tended to explode when killed, or turn into toxic gas.This is a bad game even if you don't think of the original.  But you can't not think of the original while playing this, especially near the end, because it shoves the first game in your face at every opportunity.  And if you're going to do that, by god you MUST live up to the first game.  And when the first game is Deus Ex, that's hard to do.  This game doesn't even try.It's best avoided.  On every count.

												The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												Deus Ex 2: Invisible War was Ion Storm Austin's first console game and a game that would later be described as having a "troubled development" by its creators. Many fans of the original game were quick to slam this game on release for being a "dumbed down" mess built for the console gamers.Like its predecessor, Deus Ex 2 is a First-Person Shooter / Role-Playing Game with stealth elements. Set twenty years after the events of Deus Ex, you play the role of Alex D, a student at Tarsus Academy. After being rescued from a terrorist attack that destroyed the entire city of Chicago, you are woken in your room by an assault on the Tarsus Academy facility in which you live. From there, the plot thickens as you are thrown into a world of corporate, government and ancient global conspiracies.Writing a sequel for Deus Ex would always be a difficult task because the first Deus Ex has multiple endings depending on how the player wanted to complete the game. All the endings were radically different and so, for Deus Ex 2, they chose to set the game around a mixture of two of Deus Ex's endings, which might not make logical sense given the nature of those two particular endings which I won't spoil here.Just like the previous Deus Ex, from start to finish, you have multiple ways to deal with any given situation and depending on what you do, the game will adapt accordingly. People will react to how you behave and can affect the course of the game and the only way you can Game Over is if you die.The game even offers a bit more flexibility with regards to factions over the previous game. Deus Ex had a few moments where some characters, even though they might have been killable later in the story, would be essentially invincible until their moment of demise arrives. Some might argue that this was necessary to keep the plot going but in Deus Ex 2, everyone is killable as soon as you meet them and the game can adapt with no problems. This is one of the moments in which Deus Ex 2 has an advantage over its predecessor, albeit a very small one.The story is also very good. It is not as paranoid or as quirky as the first Deus Ex and in some places, especially at the beginning, it feels slightly rushed and not enough things feel very well explained. All becomes clear in time however and putting the pieces together is just as good as it ever was.The game also has a very sci-fi feel to it. The art and sound design, devices you use and the omnipresent blue lighting all make the game feel as if its set further into the future than it probably intended to feel.Being made for the Xbox as well as PC, Deus Ex 2 has a few differences in terms of its inventory and its level design. Gone is the intricate inventory management of the first game. Instead, it was been replaced with six simple slots. Each slot can store one object or a group of objects stacked which means that three packets of Soy food take up exactly the same amount of space in your inventory as a Rocket Launcher. Some items such as energy cells and multi-tools also have a problem stacking correctly and there is no way to stack them manually.The level design also has undergone a huge change. Whilst the levels in the first Deus Ex were large but void of much detail, the levels in Deus Ex 2, whilst having dynamic lighting and were nicely detailed for a 2003 game, are extremely small in size. The modified Unreal engine they used for the game is butchered beyond belief. You will find yourself bumping into loading zones around every fifth corner. This probably has something to do with the game designed for the Xbox and its measly 64MB of RAM.The skill system that was present in the first game has been completely removed and the augmentation system has been replaced with a more streamlined system where you can choose one of three potential upgrades for specific areas of the body. You can upgrade the ability three times or, if you no longer want that particular ability, replace it with another of your choosing, though you'll have to find the Biomod canisters to start and advance your newly chosen skill.And then there's the Universal Ammo system which is, depending in your point of view, the worst or an interesting aspect of the game. All the guns in the game use the same kind of ammunition simply known as Universal Ammo. Different guns use up a different amount of universal ammo per shot so, for example, the pistol will use a small amount of universal ammo whereas the sniper rifle will use up a bigger amount. Weapons can be modified to use less ammo, destroy glass without setting off alarms attached to them and more.For all its small faults and bugs, Deus Ex 2 is a well made game and is head and shoulders above what was on store shelves around the time of its release. It's not a bad game and as long as you go into it not expecting it to be exactly like the first Deus Ex, you'll have a lot of fun with this game.

												This DX:IW is borked on so many ends just short of horrible. The Maps are so small you can cross them in 20 seconds,  and the map design, even in one level varies heavly between nice and uninspired. E.g. in the Deus Ex there was a level where you had to crawl through the vents of an airfield. Then it was totally cool, the version in DX:IW is a pitiful reminisence at best. There are quite some references like this and they all are heavy handedly integrated. The inventory handling is very clunky, combat is boring and undemanding and gets totally destroyed once you get the Mag Rail Gun. The Story may feature some ethical aspects but none of your decisions matters, ever. On top of it, each of the 4 ending sucks. Even more than the totally borked AI and ultra stiff character animation.The only good thing about this game is that the devs took care that you can go through it mostly stealthy and none-violent and there are often more intelligent ways to solve a problem than shooting. Exploring is very limit and just sufficient enough to make the stealth manouvers work. But this is not enough to waste you time with this game. Either play the great first DX game (again), Human Revolution or Binary Domain, or something else.PS: YES, I played that game to the end, all 4 of them. But Steam does not seem to register.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												So as far as I can work out, for this sequel they figured "hey let's make it for a console," at which point they ripped the guts out of the game to simplify it for a console audience that couldn't type in numbers, logins, didn't want to read bunches of stuff, allocate skill points or have a working inventory and in fact mostly just wanted to shoot stuff in the face with minimal complications. Then they looked at the limitations imposed by that console and they made the areas claustrophobically small and mangled the game engine they were using so that the far too frequent load screens take an inordinately long time to load (and bounce you to the desktop while they're doing it just to add to their immersion breaking act). It becomes at some points not unusual to spend 15 seconds traversing an area hitting a loading screen, waiting, spending another 15 seconds moving across the next area, waiting...So so far they've mangled the game contents, the interface, the world detail and the engine. Oh yeah and the weird designs of some areas make absolutely no sense whatsoever. Whatever could be left? The story? Surely that's got to be good, after all that's part of what made this series great, right? Well, no. Between the odd character animations (which weirdly make the characters look *less* natural than the first game) and the god awful factions all of whom appear to be filled with entirely awful people who elicit no sympathy whatsoever you are left either having to roll a dice and decide which of the awful factions to join in with or alternatively just running missions for whoever you feel like. None of it really makes a huge difference though as (as per the first) you are offered a nice clear cut choice to get each ending in the end. In terms of the actual storyline, with everyone so unlikable as you learn to hate them all you'll also realise just how thoroughly they have butchered the story of the first game by trying to include all three of the endings from that in the current timeline which is a mistake because it massively reduces the possibilities going forwards, and also completely trivialises the (actually interesting) choice the player had to make at the end of Deus Ex.If you enjoyed Deus Ex, don't buy this game. Really. Truly. Just skip it. Read a synopsis or something if you need to know how the story goes.

content:
y 8, 2014
Coffins used to be built with holes in them, attached to six feet of copper tubing and a bell. The tubing would allow air for victims buried under the mistaken impression they were dead. In a certain small town Harold, the local gravedigger, upon hearing a bell one night, went to go see if it was children pretending to be spirits. Sometimes it was also the wind. This time, it wasn't either. A voice from below begged and pleaded to be unburied."Are you Sarah O'Bannon?" Harold asked."Yes!" The muffled voice asserted."You were born on September 17, 1827?""Yes!""The gravestone here says you died on February 20, 1857.""No, I'm alive, it was a mistake! Dig me up, set me free!""Sorry about this, ma'am," Harold said, stepping on the bell to silence it and plugging up the copper tube with dirt. "But this is August. Whatever you are down there, you sure as hell ain't alive no more, and you ain't comin' up."

content:
r 12, 2016
												With my review about the original Deus Ex  (click here to read that) and now this review for Invisible War, you’d think I have something against the series. I’m giving these games a shot but lost interest in both very quickly. This time I could barely make it to an hour and a half before calling it quits. There are some echoed statements from my previous review, including:+Default mapping of buttons is pretty nonsensical. +Uninteresting story+Bad voice actingI didn’t find the new HUD to be that bad and the enemy AI has definitely been improved over the first game. Invisible War also follows the original with a seemingly good amount of story and things to uncover that flesh out the plot. I used the Unified Texture Pack mod and widescreen support utility. Those 2 combined did make the game look good for its age, even at 1440p. The loading points are a bit strange. It will drop back to the desktop, flash a white screen and then reload. This takes a good 10 seconds or so and can be irritating. I’m 0-2 for liking Deus Ex games…but I’m hoping Human Revolution will snap me out of it.

content:
8, 2015
												Bean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s.

content:
ber 22, 2013
												0/10It's true what they say: This is the worst sequel I've ever played, not fit to hold a candle to the original. Doesn't add to the plot at all either, as the other games were set before this one.Let's start with the Protagonist (I can't say "Player character" because there is absolutely no trace of character to be found in Alex D.) Nothing but a dull monotone voice and a refusal to commit to anything. "I'll think about it" is a catchphrase which Alex often repeats, but sadly this thought never leads to any resolution. Alex never truly expresses an opinion about anything, or takes a stand for any of the rival factions on offer.After the numbness of the main lead. the bland voice acting is another point where nobody seems willing to stand out. It's like a scene out of Equilibrium where everybody is terrified of showing some emotion, even when trying to convert you to a religion.The many factions set against each other are equally apathetic. If you decide to gun their agents down for no reason and steal their stuff, or even to trash an entire building of theirs, they'll forgive you if you run a small fetch quest for them, and if you decide to slaughter them all again, they won't hold a grudge.All of this combines to stifle any RPG aspects of the game. There's no role to play, and even if there were, there are no real choices by which to express that role. The anti-rpg agenda is continued by the removal of skill points and even ammo types. Your crossbow takes exactly the same ammo as your rocket launcher, which results in tactical choices being minimised.If all of this isn't bad enough to put you off, all the maps are ridiculously tiny, and yet still take over 90 seconds to load. In a fetch quest within one building you will literally spend more time on loading screens than in the actual game. IF it ever actually loads, and doesn't Crash to Desktop.

												Deus Ex:  Invisible War is just as full of conspiracy, and interesting real world parallels as part one.  I have heard and seen mamy people complain that you ar not as free as you were in the first Deus Ex, but I did not notice this.  I find Invisible War to be a more refined experience.  You still get to hack, mod yourself, and choose if you want to be stealthy, melee, hack or whatever.  It's still a multiple ending affair.  This game is a sequal to the first game story wise, and you will run into people and items from the first game, but you do not need to have played part one to understand the story or gameplay of this game.   I love Deus Ex, and Dues Ex: Invisible War both.

content:
y 23, 2014
												I recommend this game, with a catch. If you absolutely loved the story of Deus Ex, then this game is a must play, but not until half-way through when it really starts getting good. That Deus Ex: Invisible War is an inferior sequel has been stated by many people before me. The interface has been streamlined to the point of ridiculousness. My favorite part of Deus Ex was that you actually felt like a hacker. The keypads and terminals had an interface where you actually typed in the numbers and logons. You felt cool. This one does it automatically.The game is much shorter, which normally would be a knock, but considering the circumstances under which I played it, it was it's greatest asset.Let me explain. I never played it in 2003, but today, it is absolutely broken. The areas are small, which often force you onto the loading screen. The loading screen is a nightmare. I looked up every fix available, but none of them worked. Let me explain the situation (this will sound crazy, and unless you really care about the story, like I did, you will probably quit playing). The game freezes on every loading screen, without fail. Every loading screen, you must ctrl alt del and end the non responsive program. After about 1 minute or 2, the game pops up again without being prompted and will load normally. The areas are cramped, so there are a lot of loading screens, and every time you die, it goes back to the title screen, so you have to do this process again. Because I was so invested in the goings on, I developed a system. Every time the game loads, I would do homework until it popped up again. When the difficulty ramped up near the end, I edited the .ini file to make me invincible. Now, don't get me wrong, I'm hardcore. I can beat most games without cheats. I did it for my sanity.Another problem with this system is that it doesn't track my playtime on Steam. The game is about 10 hours long, but Steam only shows me as having played an hour. That time is only the amount of time I waited for the game to load before I figured out how to play it.So, the gameplay is weaker, the interface is terrible, and it's broken beyond belief. Why do I recommend it, then? Because, especially near the end, the story is fascinating and a great continuation of the plot of Deus Ex. I put up with the madness because I could not wait for what happened next. So, if you are fully immersed in the universe and are able to put up with everything else, I recommend this game. If you're not okay with anything I described, it's probably not worth it.

8, 2016
												I'd write a real review if I could get the game to work.(Based on original Xbox memories) Honestly not a bad game but just not as good as the others in the series, get it on console instead if you have the option.EDIT: I finally messed around with the game to try and get it to work now that the new Deus Ex is finally released.Game can't find steam?-Copy (don't cut/move) the Steam.dll file from your steam folder to Steam\steamapps\common\Deus Ex Invisible War\SystemCan't load the game or make it past the main menu?-Limit the game to only 1 core (I personally do this through the task manager via details>affinity every time I launch the game)These were the only two problems I had with running the game, I won't guarantee help with any other problems and usually google is a good starting point anyway. It still has a lot of annoyances whether it be how old the game is, the quality of the port, or specific problems with your rig. The biggest problem I have is how the game loads new areas but it is a small price to pay for not being able to play on my now broken original xbox.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2016
												Deus Ex: Invisible War is a bit dissapointing sequel of Deus Ex. yet it delivers a great graphic, combat and 3d model. the story is quite undercooked because i feel some parts of the story can be better and more meaningful but it succesfully delivers deep choices about humanity, conspiracies, conflict which makes the player think even more.that being said, Deus Ex: Invisible Wars lacks of character developments expecially for Alex D. . the lack of Alex D's character developemnt makes the players fail to connect with Alex. i also always choose female Alex because i think she has deeper personality and is quite likeable but nevertheless Alex D doesn't really do something to really make the players invested to her character but some characters in Invisible War are really good, such as JC Denton and TracerTong and other characters who tells you about many things that is kept secret in the world, etc etc. even though i can clearly say IW's story fails short if it's compared with Deus Ex or Human Revolution.  on the other hand, the gameplay and graphic significantly improved, it also has a very good atmposhere to each locations and it's really great to see the developer (Ion Storm) experimented with the HUD and other stuff. but there's one thing i can't forgive about this game is it has multiple .exe(s) which means that on Steam, you can't take screenshots via Steam Overlay because Steam is connected with the the main menu.exe where the in game is connected to in-game.exe , it's a mystery why Ion Storm set up this multiple .exe which causes other issues in the game which is if you travel to other location, you instantly are brought back to Steam and 1 second later you are back in the game, which is totally annoying.Deus Ex: Invisible War made me a little dissapointed but it also made me fresh to look at Deus Ex universe with a broader view. Invisible War is still a good game though.if you're new to Deus Ex series, i recommend you play Human Revolution then the original Deus Ex. i cannot recommend Invisible War enough, except if you're already a fan of Deus Ex but beware, don't set up your expectations too high.i still recommend you to play this game AFTER you play Deus Ex or Human Revolution (or even Mankind Divided perhaps). 7/10

content:
ber 24, 2016
												I am in a very odd camp. I love this game. I love it because it's a game that offers you choice. Because of this the environments are condensed, the side missions are short (yet impactful) and the game itself is honestly one of the better examples of how to have choice effect your game.This game is well noted for having odd technical issues. The UI is laggy and some of the gameplay choices such as inventory slots being 1 size fits all and the universal ammo not forcing people to use different weapons.If you are able to look past the above three flaws then the game is amazing. The narrative is great, the side missions give you depth into the world and the environments while small are very well done. I've played through this game a number of times from both sides of it. You can get dropped off in different places for each new location, you can side with eather faction at any given point in the story and you can actually make meaningful choices at the end as to which faction will rule the world. Spoilers are below Not only that but it digs up the past in the best way possible. It determines that Paul and JC are alive and possibly well if you pick that faction. It boils the game down into a nice package.In a way I am happy the modern games didn't try to tack onto the series ending that invisible war created because it ended it in a casade of choice.So for those who value choice and well written narrative the game is worth it.

It's still pretty fun, assuming you can get it to cooperate with your hardware, but it just doesn't shine as bright as its other titles.

												It doesn’t equal the predecessor, however this is a solid FPS/RPG cyberpunk hybrid with fun gameplay, gripping story (despite far-fetched twists), much optional stuff and several factions (tricking your enemies into attacking each other is always hilarious). My main complaint concerns the unbalanced and limited biomod system: maximum level 3 can be reached very easily, while some biomods (e.g. aggressive defense drone, vision enhancement) completely pale in comparison to the really useful ones (e.g. thermal masking, regeneration). All in all, if you like cyberpunk games, don’t miss this one.
