29, 2015
												Deus Ex is by far one of the greatest RPG stealth adventure games ever made.  And I'm not entirely sure why DX: IW gets so much distain among the fanbase.  The game itself wasn't as good as the first and third; but it was still a very well made, and very fun game.  You needed to download a program to get it to run in widescreen, and optionally an improvement to the textures; but that's not a necessary thing to do.  The controls are great, the graphics are great, the story is great, just everything is great.  But if I was to nitpick something,  augments are dumbed down heavily, skills got removed because why not, everything uses a universal plasma ammo-  which honestly makes sense considering in DX1 and DX3 which are both prequels to DX2, you see plasma weaponry slowly becoming quite popular; it just wasn't mass produced too far just yet; although it is confusing trying to see how they had the time to universally produce and distribute plasma weaponry and ammo after the collapse.

												The only invisible thing in here is the game itself.This game is broken. Don't buy it.The first thing you see after installing this game on Win7 and starting it up is a black screen or your own desktop. If you spend a couple of hours researching on the web, do some weird things with the compatibility of the game files and have a bit of luck, you're able to launch the game and enter the first level.However, the problems don't end here. Every time you finish a level, the game freezes. When that happens, you have to manually kill the game's process and wait 5 minutes. Only then does the next level load. It is worth to note here that levels in this game are INCREDIBLY short, so that will happen rather often.I am well aware of the fact that the game is old but it's not an excuse, really. I've got many games older than Invisible War and, with some tweaking, they can still run up to this day.Oh, and I heard that this problem concerns only people with AMD graphics cards. Nvidia is OP, I guess.

content:
er 13, 2015
Pros:-Character customization is still fun, just much more limited-Gameplay is still fun, just... not like the other Deus Ex games-Multiple solutions to problems-Decent amount of content-Moderate replayability-Actually a decent standalone gameCons:-Decidedly awful as a Deus Ex game-Dated graphics-Choices over entire game are basically made meaningless-Don't walk forward while using the flamethrowerOverall: With the exception of Deus Ex: The Fall, which we just don't talk about, this is the most dumbed down Deus Ex experience out there.  Character customization is much more limited, the solutions to problems are all much simpler, and the storyline is just... sorry.  Ninety percent of the game consists of making choices that have zero effect on the endgame, despite feeling important at the time.  This game suffered because it was the sequel to the absolutely outstanding Deus Ex, and after waiting for a sequel, fans were delivered this disappointment.  They wanted more Deus Ex, and this failed to deliver.That said, this was the first Deus Ex game I ever played, and it was good enough to make me want to play the others.  It's a fun game, with fun gameplay and intriguing mechanics.  If I had played the other Deus Ex games first and played this one after, yes, I would have been disappointed.  This is a failed attempt to match the other games' depth and customization.  But it's still a fun game.  This of it as Deus Ex Lite.  You'll get the Deus Ex experience, but nowhere near the level of Deus Ex 1 or Human Revolution.  It is worth playing, even as a Deus Ex game.  The plot is passable, as are the NPCs.  There is a "true pacifist" route to be taken if you desire, and there are some fun easter egg references to the first game buried in here.  For $6.99, the game is fantastic and fun, just don't expect a Deus Ex level experience.  Go in with that mindset, and you'll probably have a good time.Bottom Line: Worth the price tag.

												Now here we are a follow on from Deus Ex, I was excited when I first bought this game ready to see how my activities in the first game would shape the world around me and then I played it!!!!!! The story made no sense at all at the end of Deus Ex you can only pick one out come not all so why for the love of pound cake did they make it so JC Denton did all of them it makes no sense it would have been easy to make a save importer that tells the game what happened in the first so your choices would make a new story each time you play or even easier make an application in the launcher or at the start of the game that asks the user to say what they chose to do in major game changing events like "Did you kill Anna Navarre on the jet" or option 2 "Did you Kill Anna Navarre at UNATCO HQ". content:
ber 5, 2013
												As Deus Ex proved itself be one of the most immersive stealth/shooter/RPG's ever developed, any sequel would certainly be hard-pushed to be its equal. Sadly, DX: Invisible War received mostly mixed and somewhat negative reviews on this issue. At first, like most, I felt a little disappointed by the end of my first playthrough. For a game developed four years after the original, I expected some new, exciting ground to be explored and ideas for  improvement on the original. Many fans took an instant dislike to DX:IW for one, some, or all the following reasons: 1. The graphics weren't much of an improvement (and perhaps worse) than the original, 2. The maps seemed claustrophobic and clunky when compared to fantastic spacious environments featured in the original DX, 3. Combat wasn't much better (again, perhaps worse), 4. Voice dialogue for the most part fell flat, boring, without emotion and lacked credibility, equally less memorable as the characters themselves, 5.That the gameplay had been too simplified and lacked ambition, ie: loss of ammo variation, skills system dropped, no XP points, absence of lockpicks, etc, 6. That while Alex D could take on secondary missions, they turned out to be nothing more than minor distractions far too easily accomplished (amongst many things that DX: HR had got right), 7. That the game itself was too short - it could be completed in about 10 hours first playthrough, while completion of its predecessor perhaps required four times as long!But then something pulled me back to play it again, even a third time....Certainly, if you can see past the shortcomings listed above, then you might be able to enjoy IW's more positive aspects. For example, I considered IW's weapon mods to be far more interesting than the ones in DX. I also enjoyed a couple of innovative ideas: spider-bot bombs were tremendous fun, while the health leech and bot-domination were fantastic ideas included in augmentation. Also, Alex doesn't share JC Denton's frustrating inability to climb over waist-high crates! As the world has moved 20 years on from DX, so too has nano-augmentation: the cybernetically enhanced Omar deal in black market goods, while nanite detonaters and harmful nanite clouds lend IW an intriguing backdrop to the conspiratorial story. The Greys make a return and this time around given a more sentient role in IW's affairs.  Holograms also make a welcome return - although these are far more complex than the mere communication types featured in DX: such AI constucts styled in the image and voice of a fictitious pop star of this future, NG Resonance, are able to interact with people, even licensed to offer rewards for solving crimes (since as a precaution such holograms are connected to police databases)...not to mention report on everything said by someone suspicious. Another nice little idea. The game music - while not quite as memorable as DX's - helped enhance the atmosphere of each mission. There were some great angles on the story itself: one particular mission meant a return to some place from DX (I don't want to spoil it for those yet to play IW!) as if everything had come full circle. It was quite a satisfying, if somewhat poignant moment. Project Leader Harvey Smith was given the chance to explain why events turned sour: DX:IW suffered a rushed development shipped with both good and bad ideas due to fan feedback mismanagement, there was little teamwork chemistry within the studio, and the need to cater for a console version confused matters even further. Not in the least he was going through a divorce. Later that same year, another big project by Ion Storm  was completed in the form of Thief: Deadly Shadows - and really that's what demanded DX director Warren Spector's attention. In hindsight, Invisible War should have been developed with a full studio complement in the same pioneering spirit as the original DX. Even if this meant waiting a couple of years for an improved engine to come along, the planning of more in-depth characters with credible dialogue, gameplay design and sharper mechanics, intriguing secondary missions, and complex map levels. Perhaps, one day, there will be a 'remake' of Deus Ex: Invisible War...?One last note: if you have played Deus Ex, then be prepared that Inivisible War is a somewhat different beast to its predecessor. And please let me know whether you agree, disagree, or have something you'd like to add!

content:

												Tags : 1PStealth - First Person StealthDeux Ex : Invisible War, Second in the franchise, does not have the scope, narrative buildup and flair, charisma of the original, nor does it have the mechanical complexity of it, relinquishing some of its RPG hybrid features in favor of a more streamlined experience. No more skills, experience, biomods are no longer permanent and can be re-allocated. What hurts this game the most is the general cluelessness of the main protagonist, the berserk nature of the AI if it catches you red handed doing something illegal like theft, and will not return to a non hostile stance once triggered. The game compares fairly well to say system shock 2, with a similar level of complexity, a more approachable level design.The plot has some layers and some reveals, and multiple factions with different objectives will all try to sway the main protagonist's actions in their favor, it is sometimes, even often, possible to play the game trying to maximize rewards by playing on multiple fronts but the game might be more enjoyable picking a side, and living with the consequences of treating the opposing camp as ennemy. There are at least three different endings with vastly different choices.The game does not tie-in very well with the rest of the deus ex series, although it is the second in the series, the events happen last chronologically in the deus ex lore, and it is sometimes easier to treat this world as an alternate universe version of the deus ex franchise than a direct continuation and makes the game more enjoyable.An all-in-one mod is available for modern resolutions, texture packs, and some bugfixes but you can just as well get the most out of this game through the vanilla experience as well.I would recommend this game for fans of fps/rpg hybrid games, those who like sci fi, but the cyberpunk or deus exy aspects fall a little short.

er 6, 2014
												Haven't played through much of the game yet so I can't give an evaluation of the story. This game is definitely the worst pc port I've seen yet, admittedly I steer clear of the really bad ports but this is definitely a red flag. Compared to the original game which actually seems to handle anything I threw at it fine (played the game in a window and used a tool to make it borderless) this game flat out refuses to cooperate.Max resolution available to me is 1280x1024, you can force change this in the ini but the game automatically re-writes settings when it reloads (which is often, more later) so I had to forcibly deny access via Windows security settings. Windowed mode is also an option via .ini edit however do not expect borderless, the game flips out and the window simply becomes invisible if you attempt to modify anything about the size of the window while it is open, whether that be borderless using a tool or maximizing it in task manager to get rid of the ugly gap beneath the window.The game also reloads often, loading in any area seems to do this as do some cutscenes, and believe me this is often. As a result of the console release presumably and the limited hardware of said consoles at the time the actual areas loaded in at once are horrifically small (Funnily enough, a criticism of the newer "The Fall" title too). However, this is not just loading screens, the game actually reloads itself entirely each time it does so, other reviews were certainly not exaggerating when they said you will spend more time watching loading screens than in game.There are some other minor issues arising already, the controls are certainly not as freely rebindable as the first game and the UI compared to the previous game is clearly console-based though workable on PC. Other issues of varying magnitude by individual preference are a somewhat lacking options menu and more.Overall, as far as a PC title goes this game has a whole host of issues, this game is certainly not for the impatient and many will find the port frustrating to work with (hopefully some of my points help people get the game working how they like it).As for the story, o far it seems like it could be promising, seen a few Deus Ex 1 style options, the core mechanics are still there though I'm not well they're handled later down the line. So far the game has been very much like a tutorial (or perhaps the game as a whole is too linear). There is certainly a clear conspiracy style storyline (as you would expect for Deus Ex) though perhaps its a little forced this time, as I mentioned I haven't played much so far, only about to leave the first area and I am already being presented by two very distinct sides and making a major choice between the two.This review isn't really to cover the storyline though, if you've previously played Deus Ex you already know the reputation of Invisible War and are considering playing it because you want to find out what happens after the 1st game, just keep in mind the hurdles in doing so I mentioned earlier. I do think I will play this to the end regardless, just might be in shorter bursts than HR and DX1.

content:
y 23, 2014
												I recommend this game, with a catch. If you absolutely loved the story of Deus Ex, then this game is a must play, but not until half-way through when it really starts getting good. That Deus Ex: Invisible War is an inferior sequel has been stated by many people before me. The interface has been streamlined to the point of ridiculousness. My favorite part of Deus Ex was that you actually felt like a hacker. The keypads and terminals had an interface where you actually typed in the numbers and logons. You felt cool. This one does it automatically.The game is much shorter, which normally would be a knock, but considering the circumstances under which I played it, it was it's greatest asset.Let me explain. I never played it in 2003, but today, it is absolutely broken. The areas are small, which often force you onto the loading screen. The loading screen is a nightmare. I looked up every fix available, but none of them worked. Let me explain the situation (this will sound crazy, and unless you really care about the story, like I did, you will probably quit playing). The game freezes on every loading screen, without fail. Every loading screen, you must ctrl alt del and end the non responsive program. After about 1 minute or 2, the game pops up again without being prompted and will load normally. The areas are cramped, so there are a lot of loading screens, and every time you die, it goes back to the title screen, so you have to do this process again. Because I was so invested in the goings on, I developed a system. Every time the game loads, I would do homework until it popped up again. When the difficulty ramped up near the end, I edited the .ini file to make me invincible. Now, don't get me wrong, I'm hardcore. I can beat most games without cheats. I did it for my sanity.Another problem with this system is that it doesn't track my playtime on Steam. The game is about 10 hours long, but Steam only shows me as having played an hour. That time is only the amount of time I waited for the game to load before I figured out how to play it.So, the gameplay is weaker, the interface is terrible, and it's broken beyond belief. Why do I recommend it, then? Because, especially near the end, the story is fascinating and a great continuation of the plot of Deus Ex. I put up with the madness because I could not wait for what happened next. So, if you are fully immersed in the universe and are able to put up with everything else, I recommend this game. If you're not okay with anything I described, it's probably not worth it.

content:
, 2014
												I'm in for a series marathon, and playing each back-to-back seems like a good way to examine the evolution of the whole. I have to disagree with most of the negative feelings toward this title, because a "bad" connotation or "worst in the series" designation to a Deus Ex game still makes for a really great experience. Why? The vastly improved physics certainly don't hurt. That's fun in its own right. Most of the worst reviews I've ever seen lobbed at this sequel come from long-time fans of the original game, and if I had to choose my own least favorite difference between the two, honestly, it is the loss of the corner-leaning function that felt so good in the first; but to me, that is one of the few reductions where many other gameplay elements are definitely improved upon and streamlined. I know that can be a bad word in gaming. Streamlined can easily mean less. Here, it applies. One of the most common critiques I've heard, from professional critics and caring fans alike, has to do with Invisible War's level design. This seems hollow, I think, given the way this refers almost exclusively to size and wide-open feeling areas. In fact, the generally smaller levels of this sequel are far more efficient in their use of space -- something that seems to help it run better, actually, apart from some crashing which might be rooted in the series' early, unlucky business choices over bad drivers/graphics support for their engine -- you will quickly find so many tasks to complete that your head will be spinning, each with multiple choices, outcomes, and courses to get there. If you play many angles and think on your feet, trying to outwit what only ~seem~ like restraints on the surface, you will not only feel like an absolute bada$$ very early in the game, but be gratified at what you can do with some good creative planning. This is very much in keeping with the spirit of the Deus Ex name, the first mission areas alone having as many or more different paths to victory as any level in the original (if you only look hard enough), with all the cleverness and depth of story and world as every competent fan has come to expect. It doesn't always look or sound pretty, but in plenty of moments remains reasonably passable. Indeed, the beauty of this one, a learning experience in terms of its basic design aspects, are the ways in which your decisions invariably tie together in an emergent fashion. The greatest showcase of its true depth is probably best explained by pointing out how no two walkthroughs for it seem to contain all of the same information, each being subtly different and personal with an active community of explorers necessary to continually discover new things. You might find something new and unexpected, too. I feel like I do each time I play Invisible War, no different than the original, no less than any other standard of the series. Heck, to provide one non-spoiling testimony, even the most obscure details such as the names of coffee chains they included as a side-plot/metaphorical example to hint at the greater whole of this mystery, are remarkably witty little nods to our every day real life... though they seem almost laughably dumb if you don't know, I realize, that's exactly the point -- the whole story highlights how ignorance can be taken advantage of and manipulated from above, after all... Pequod and Queequeg were two principle characters in Melville's "MobyDick," and the name of the ship's first mate in that old, famous story just happened to be "Starbuck." See the connection? Did you ever realize? It takes digging, sometimes. This game, like the whole series, is overflowing with little details of that sort, the creators working well with whatever they had at hand, and is no less rooted in literature, history, or the greatest schools of philosophical thought than its counterparts. If you are an avid reader, especially of classics, this will be a fun game for you -- as would any Deus Ex game. It is a title that means your brain will be taxed, you'll go to bed either dreaming about your experiences or lying restlessly awake over its implications, and left saying, "wow," at every new twist. Yes, this one seems smaller, and yes, this might be the easiest of the series if you already have a grasp of how to play from the first, but there is a ton of detail within this title which can turn out to be just as rewarding as any other to carry that glorious logo. It's great. For my own part, today, feeling like a kid again, Invisible War was as equally amazing in its own day as the original had been, before.

"You are only minimally modified. We can help you correct this."Deus Ex: Invisible War is a for the most part linear FPS-RPG in a sinister Sci-Fi setting. It's graphics pale compared to other titles using the same engine, levels seem a bit confined especially when compared to the first Deus Ex and the inventory is tiny - design concessions that had to be made in order for a release on the original Xbox console to be possible. Frequent loading screens in between small level sections can be somewhat annoying and take between 20-30 seconds even on a SSD. (Save regularly to avoid having to replay lenghty sections because very rarely the game did crash on me and even corrupted a save-file once.)Sounds bad? Nah. I played through the game close to its release and played through it again just now. Don't be fooled into thinking this is the abysmal game enthusiasts of the first game often make it out to be. It's less complex in just about every aspect, yes, but it still an enjoyable experience for fans of the series and FPS-RPG fans alike. Shooting feels fine, weapons and gadgets/biomods are fun to use, different approaches to enemy encounters / completing objectives are possible and encouraged, even some plot altering decisions can be made. Overall it was an enjoyable 20 hour experience (if you take your time like me, and try to find up to six special weapons well hidden in the game). A recommendation when on sale, especially for fans of the first game for story reasons and for fans of the cyberpunk/noir/dark Sci-Fi genres. (Note: I ran this game on Win 8.1 64-Bit using the community texture pack, at 1080p resolution, 120 FOV and reduced HUD size. Using all these tweaks (to be found in the community section here on steam) I even found it visually to be a somewhat pleasing experience.)

Pros:-Character customization is still fun, just much more limited-Gameplay is still fun, just... not like the other Deus Ex games-Multiple solutions to problems-Decent amount of content-Moderate replayability-Actually a decent standalone gameCons:-Decidedly awful as a Deus Ex game-Dated graphics-Choices over entire game are basically made meaningless-Don't walk forward while using the flamethrowerOverall: With the exception of Deus Ex: The Fall, which we just don't talk about, this is the most dumbed down Deus Ex experience out there.  Character customization is much more limited, the solutions to problems are all much simpler, and the storyline is just... sorry.  Ninety percent of the game consists of making choices that have zero effect on the endgame, despite feeling important at the time.  This game suffered because it was the sequel to the absolutely outstanding Deus Ex, and after waiting for a sequel, fans were delivered this disappointment.  They wanted more Deus Ex, and this failed to deliver.That said, this was the first Deus Ex game I ever played, and it was good enough to make me want to play the others.  It's a fun game, with fun gameplay and intriguing mechanics.  If I had played the other Deus Ex games first and played this one after, yes, I would have been disappointed.  This is a failed attempt to match the other games' depth and customization.  But it's still a fun game.  This of it as Deus Ex Lite.  You'll get the Deus Ex experience, but nowhere near the level of Deus Ex 1 or Human Revolution.  It is worth playing, even as a Deus Ex game.  The plot is passable, as are the NPCs.  There is a "true pacifist" route to be taken if you desire, and there are some fun easter egg references to the first game buried in here.  For $6.99, the game is fantastic and fun, just don't expect a Deus Ex level experience.  Go in with that mindset, and you'll probably have a good time.Bottom Line: Worth the price tag.

												The original Deus Ex (DE1) is my favorite game of all time … so I looked forward to its sequel (Deus Ex: Invisible War, DE2)As each game of the series, you will move in an awesome cyberpunk environment, which is as complex and consistent as in the best SF books. Cyberpunk games are usually really interesting because they often deal with a lot of interesting concepts such as transhumanism, bioethics, economy and law.### Pros:- Fair story & good cyberpunk environment involving corporations, secret societies and charismatic characters- Large number of side quests (you have to speak with most NPC to find them)- Your choices will have major consequences on the subsequent missions, and there are several endings### Cons:The gameplay was oversimplified by contrast to the original game. That was the consequence of the parallel development for both PC and Xbox-1- Tiny levels and long loading screen every 5 min- Inventory management system was simplified- AI can be improvableIn DE1, some guns had 3 different ammo types … and in DE2 all weapons use the same “universal” ammo … rofl !### Conclusion:DE2 is not a bad game, but it is not the worthy successor of DE1 ... that's why most people badly criticised it !13/20

27, 2013
												I'm so happy that I went back and played Invisible War again after so many years. When I installed all I really had was a few sketchy memories about a couple of plot twists, coupled with smiles about my first experience with marijuana and ragdoll physics. By the end though, it was clear that I had been playing a game that, despite the outdated textures and AI, still beats many of the modern-day FPS shooters hands down in every important aspect. What I mean by that, is that Invisible War delivers an excellent plot with multiple endings and engrossing moral choices; often comical side missions, that stay well within the realms of possibility, leading to increased immersion while giving the player a little change-up from the main "Spy-spy-genocide-jihad" storyline - interestingly, something Human Revolution fails to do and is less of a game for it; and the abilty to access it all playing whichever way you want. Want to sneak? Cool bro, go for it. Want to burn people alive and laugh at them while they run around screaming? Go nuts. Want to just beat everyone into a bloody pulp and then throw the bodies off a building into a skip bin? (Is me fave) Well you can do that too!Invisible War also has many features modern shooters (and I can't understand why) don't include. Modifying my guns is A MUST for me in any action game, and Invisible War delivers, not only that, it gives you a legitimate ability to be non-lethal and still have a number of weapons and abilities at your disposal. So many things in this game are done better than in many later games that you really get the feeling it's still superior.This game (not franchise) is one of the best of all time for me - easily on par with the likes of Morrowind in terms of execution. Perfectly balanced gameplay.

												Total Score: 61 C+ (Deus-ish)Graphics and Art: 7Sound and Music: 5Story and Plot: 7Controls: 8Creativity and Uniqueness: 4Mood and Immersion: 7Length, Content, and Replayability: 5Functionality: 6Character Choice and Customization: 7Challenge: 5Do stuff, some of it fun!  OK, so, yes, as everyone will tell you, this game doesn't live up to the original Deus Ex, a deep creative-powerhouse that managed to not only be a thoroughly enjoyable cyberpunk game (and there are never enough cyberpunk games) but which, for the time, pushed the technology available and crossed the line from being just a fun game to adding to mankind's philosophical body of knowledge about life.  The first Deus Ex was a work on art in every sense.  Now, I'm not saying that Invisible War had nothing to say.  It had numerous useful witicisms and social and political-economic comentary.  But it wasn't quite as refined as Deus Ex the first.  But, honestly, there's a lot in this game to enjoy.  The hacking gameplay is just a blast, as you vicariously mow down enemies with the robot or turret of your choice, though it certainly could have been more.  The graphics is acceptable for the time, if uninspired, and you have a lot of options with how to take your character in terms of both story and gameplay, though you top out way too early, and there's really not much mechanical reason to do everything there is to do other than the fun of doing it.  The character development isn't nearly as involved (or excellent) as the original either.  I mean, you get money, but you won't have much to spend it on.  The game is also pretty short and somewhat lacking in the challenge department, though it does have the admirable quality of awarding intelligent tactics.  This is a good, fun game, just don't expect a great game.  And, if you're a Deus Ex fan, might as well play it...kind of...if you want to.

content:

												Tags : 1PStealth - First Person StealthDeux Ex : Invisible War, Second in the franchise, does not have the scope, narrative buildup and flair, charisma of the original, nor does it have the mechanical complexity of it, relinquishing some of its RPG hybrid features in favor of a more streamlined experience. No more skills, experience, biomods are no longer permanent and can be re-allocated. What hurts this game the most is the general cluelessness of the main protagonist, the berserk nature of the AI if it catches you red handed doing something illegal like theft, and will not return to a non hostile stance once triggered. The game compares fairly well to say system shock 2, with a similar level of complexity, a more approachable level design.The plot has some layers and some reveals, and multiple factions with different objectives will all try to sway the main protagonist's actions in their favor, it is sometimes, even often, possible to play the game trying to maximize rewards by playing on multiple fronts but the game might be more enjoyable picking a side, and living with the consequences of treating the opposing camp as ennemy. There are at least three different endings with vastly different choices.The game does not tie-in very well with the rest of the deus ex series, although it is the second in the series, the events happen last chronologically in the deus ex lore, and it is sometimes easier to treat this world as an alternate universe version of the deus ex franchise than a direct continuation and makes the game more enjoyable.An all-in-one mod is available for modern resolutions, texture packs, and some bugfixes but you can just as well get the most out of this game through the vanilla experience as well.I would recommend this game for fans of fps/rpg hybrid games, those who like sci fi, but the cyberpunk or deus exy aspects fall a little short.

content:
31, 2013
												First of all i'd like to start by saying that if your generally a PC gamer then you'd be better off sticking to the original, the first Deus Ex. Why? because Invisible War on the PC is not only difficult to run by flawed by bugs and the like. That and compared to the original, this is rather 'dumbed down' losing the skill system. However, it would be best to ignore these little irrelevancies because this game is gold compared to others on the Xbox, and possibly the best for the console in 2004. So if you're one of those who stay in all day staring at your PC screen then you better stop reading, you probably won't like this game, its for norms, not for pale kids. You do not need to have played the original to understand or enjoy this game, a rare feature amongst sequels, and the official magazines and websites that have rated this game are not wrong, "10/10 - XBM" "9/10 - OXM" Its one of the most evident games to show rag-doll physics. In other words, nearly everything is intractable, and objects move more like they would in real life, for example, in a standard FPS you can drop a gun and it will instantly be placed on the floor without movement, where as with Deus Ex, the weapon would bounce or move about depending on height and environment. This alone, adds to the games fun factor, throwing corpses through basketball hoops for example, but of course the story is what "can" keep you. I say can because you can breeze through this game without listening to a single bit of dialogue and still find yourself completing it. However, just the slightest bit of attention is required to really understand what's going on, amongst the jargon of some of the characters.Speaking of environments, Invisible War's are aces in my book. Filthy cheap apartments with sneaky fire escapes, seedy little nightclubs with VIP areas, dodgy dealings with the black market, rival coffee chains with those uptight indie ikea furniture.. its all so distinguished and refined. The feel of the game is one of the most appealing attractions because although the areas are all singly loaded, the features that they offer are remarkable, with everyday objects that you wish you could find in a normal game, ventilation shafts, rooftops, store cupboards and dumpsters. I realize that might not sound to appealing, but when you consider your character can jump to/in these places, hide in these places and basically interact with all of them makes for some pretty realistic and creative game-play. There's just that specific amount of freedom that this game offers that keeps you hooked , along with the awesome weapons and equipment found throughout, such as homing rocket launchers or Nikita's, Stun prods, Energy Blades, Rail Guns, Sniper Rifles and your basics accompanied by another array of secondary fires and grenades/mines. Basically this game allows you to interact with your surroundings as much as possible, so that you play the game you want too. You don't have to charge into a group of enemies that so many games force you to do to progress, instead, why not throw a few grenades at them to lure them in close? lay some mines on the floor? and then hop into a nearby dumpster?So in summary, if your a dedicated gamer keen to complete and be compelled in a game, its a good one, or if you love messing about and doing your own thing, once again, a quality game for you.

												Deus Ex: Invisible War is simply my favorite installment of the Deus Ex series, I played it on PS2 back in the day and wondered if it would still hold up among the RPGs of today and it is the opinion of this gamer that it does. It still has a sensible upgrade system, good story and the gameplay that although tough is comfortable. I wish that if they were going to be focusing on a era of remakes and reboots that Invisible War would get a spotlight and be remade adding more sidequests, weapons and get a scenic overhaul. The only problem I have is the map layouts can be confusing and the cities feel more like sci-fi mazes than actual places on earth.
